question: What is Mega menu add-on in Thrive?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 5 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
The Mega Menu add-on in Thrive is a feature that allows users to create and customize advanced navigation menus. To access the Mega Menu, users can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. Once in the Mega Menu, users can edit the menu by selecting the "Edit" option on the top left. The Mega Menu has an edit lock feature that ensures only one person can edit it at a time. After 30 minutes of inactivity in edit mode, the edit lock is released. To exit the edit mode, users can click on "Cancel" on the top right.

The Mega Menu settings can be accessed and edited in the "Settings" section. In the "General Settings" section, users can define the desired menu behavior, such as opening the dropdown on hover or click. Users can also choose the effect for the panel/dropdown, such as fade, slide, or push. The speed of panel rendering, line height, shadow, logo, URL, cache time, and Mega Menu position can also be configured in the "General Settings" section.

The Mega Menu add-on also allows users to configure the logo and main navigation settings. In the "Logo" section, users can configure the logo for the Mega Menu and the URL to be accessed when the logo is clicked. In the "Main Navigation" section, users can configure the preview, height, width, background color, padding, and border of the main navigation menu. Users can also configure the font, font hover, background color, item spacing, item padding, and item divider of the top-level menu items.

The Mega Menu add-on provides various settings for different levels of the menu, such as the dropdown panel, grid (column), sub-menu item (level 2), and third-level menu items. Users can customize the title, font, padding, border, and other elements of each level of the menu.

The Mega Menu add-on also supports exporting/importing configuration, sample configuration, and installation on both cloud and hosted/on-prem Jive instances. Users can export/import the configured settings, save previous configurations as backups, and install the add-on on their Jive instances.

In summary, the Mega Menu add-on in Thrive is a powerful tool that allows users to create and customize advanced navigation menus. It provides various settings for different levels of the menu, such as the dropdown panel, grid (column), sub-menu item (level 2), and third-level menu items. Users can configure the behavior, appearance, and layout of the menu to suit their needs.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 5 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
The Mega Menu Add-On in Thrive can be accessed and configured by following these steps:

1. Under Global Theme Map, select "custom" in the dropdown and then click on "Set Global Theme", so changes will be applied.
2. Add custom CSS in the Theme page:
\`\`\`
.j-header-mode-simple #top {
display: none;
}

.j-header-mode-simple #j-header-wrap {
position: relative !important;
}
\`\`\`
3. Save the Theme.
4. Go to the configuration page via the URL: \`/apps/mega-menu-add-on\` to configure the Mega Menu Add-On.

To access the Mega Menu, from the Create menu, select Advanced Navigation Configuration option. Next, select the Edit option on the top left. The Mega Menu settings will now render in an editable mode. To exit the Edit mode, click on Cancel on the top right.

The Mega Menu Add-On provides various settings and features for customization. These include:

- General Settings: Open Dropdown on (Hover/Click), Effect for panel/dropdown (None/Fade/Slide/Push), Speed of panel rendering, Line Height, Shadow, Logo, URL, Cache Time, Mega Menu Position, and Mega Menu Sticky.
- Logo: Configure the Logo for the Mega Menu and the URL to be accessed when the user selects the logo. Additional logos can be configured for each Visibility Rule.
- Main Navigation: Customize the Top Level Menu Items, including Font, Font hover, Background Color, Item Spacing, Item Padding, and Item Divider.
- Dropdown Panel: Configure the settings for the Dropdown Panel, including Preview, Panel background, Panel width, Panel padding, Column Padding, and Grid (Column) settings.
- Sub-menu Item (Level 2): Customize the settings for Sub-menu items, including Item Title, Item Font (hover), Item Background, Item Background (hover), Item Padding, and Item Border.
- Third Level Menu Items: Configure the settings for Third Level Menu items, including Item Title, Item Font (hover), Item Background, Item Background (hover), Item Padding, and Item Border.
- Exporting/Importing Configuration: Export and import the current configured settings in the Add-On on another environment or instance.
- Sample Configuration: View sample configurations for Mega Menu layouts.

The Mega Menu Add-On also provides features such as Edit Lock to ensure only one user can edit the Mega Menu at a time, and Visibility Rules to control the visibility of menu items based on user profiles.

Please note that some issues and feature requests have been reported for the Mega Menu Add-On, and updates and fixes have been released in different versions. It is recommended to keep the Add-On updated to the latest version to ensure optimal functionality.

If you encounter any specific issues or need further assistance, it is recommended to raise a support case for prompt resolution.
answer_similarity_reason: Both answers provide a detailed description of the Mega Menu add-on in Thrive, including the features, settings, and customization options. The search_phrase_answer also provides additional information about the Global Theme Map, custom CSS, and Visibility Rules.

question: what all do you know?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 June, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive is a social software platform that goes beyond Facebook and Twitter. It combines the features of social networking sites with the functionality of LinkedIn and more. In layman's terms, Jive is a tool that helps employees work better and feel more connected. It provides a better way to collaborate, share information, and communicate within an organization.

To explain Jive to a random employee, you can use the following pitch:
"Do you want a better way to work? Do you want to feel more connected? Jive is a platform that allows you to collaborate, share information, and communicate with your colleagues in a more efficient and effective way. It's like Facebook and LinkedIn, but on steroids."

Jive offers various features that can benefit an organization. Some of these features include threaded conversations, content sharing, information visualization, threaded conversations in Outlook, and quick parts in Outlook. These features help improve productivity, facilitate knowledge sharing, and enhance communication within the organization.

Jive is used by many companies, including PwC, Nike, Toshiba, Cisco, SAP, Intel, Bertelsman, Deloitte, LG Electronics, and Razorfish. These companies have found value in using Jive as a collaboration tool to improve productivity and efficiency.

Jive is a secure platform that ensures the confidentiality of information. It provides options to create private and secret groups where only members can access the content. Additionally, Jive allows users to customize their newsfeeds, making it easier to find relevant information and stay updated on the latest discussions and activities.

While Jive can be used for socializing and informal networking, it is primarily a business collaboration tool. It is designed to help employees work better and more efficiently. By using Jive, employees can find and connect with colleagues, share knowledge, and collaborate on projects. It is not just a social network like Facebook, but a tool that can significantly improve productivity and efficiency in the workplace.

In summary, Jive is a social software platform that helps employees work better and feel more connected. It combines the features of social networking sites with the functionality of LinkedIn and more. Jive offers various features such as threaded conversations, content sharing, and quick parts in Outlook. It is used by many companies and provides a secure and efficient way to collaborate and communicate within an organization.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 03 November, 2020, here is the answer:
AI assistants are becoming increasingly popular in various industries, including HR, IT support, and onboarding. There have been discussions about incorporating AI assistants into the Jive platform. For example, there is a mention of a Jive Bot on the external Jive site, and Beezy has already implemented an intelligent assistant for the digital workplace. However, it is unclear if Jive has any specific plans or roadmap for a Jive Bot. It is also mentioned that Microsoft has a Q&A maker service as part of Azure, which allows the creation of useful Q&A bots. Integration with Jive might be possible through a custom tile. As for AI translation tools, there is a mention of considering Google's AI Translation tool for translation needs within the community. The integration can be done using Jive's content translation module or by using Google Translate directly. The estimation of the amount of text to be translated can be done by analyzing the current number of characters (letters and spaces) being used in the community.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers are similar in that they both discuss Jive, a social software platform, and its features. However, the search_phrase_answer also discusses AI assistants and translation tools, which are not present in the original answer.

question: What is bunchball ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 October, 2021, here is the answer:
**Bunchball** is a gamification platform that was integrated with Jive, a collaboration software. It allowed organizations to incentivize and reward user engagement and participation within their Jive communities. However, based on the extracted information, it seems that Bunchball is no longer supported and connected to Jive. The content related to Bunchball integration should be removed.

In the past, some Jive communities reported notable success with Bunchball, seeing measurable increases in high-value activities and achieving positive business results. However, the success of Bunchball implementation depends on various factors, including the organization's culture, community objectives, and the careful design of the gamification system. It is important to create a game that aligns with the organization's goals and encourages positive and productive behavior within the community.

To achieve success with Bunchball, it is recommended to set the tone from the start, emphasizing that the game is for fun and experimentation while maintaining ethical behavior. Making the points and levels appealing can motivate participants, and rewarding recognition from others can encourage the creation of high-quality content. Launching the gamification system with a big splash, tying it to an event, and gradually introducing missions over time can sustain interest and engagement.

It is also important to watch for cheaters and address unethical behavior promptly. Cheating can undermine the integrity of the game and demotivate honest players. Fixing loopholes and punishing cheaters can help maintain fairness and ensure a positive gaming experience for all participants.

While the out-of-the-box missions provided by Bunchball may not be useful, organizations can customize the gamification system to suit their specific needs and objectives. Creating unique missions, setting up scavenger hunts, and encouraging collaboration among participants can enhance engagement and make the gamification experience more enjoyable.

It is worth noting that the information extracted is from various dates, ranging from 2012 to 2015. Therefore, it is important to verify the current status and availability of Bunchball integration with Jive before considering its implementation.

question: what is bunchball?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 October, 2021, here is the answer:
Bunchball is a gamification platform that can be integrated with Jive, a collaboration software. It allows organizations to create game-like experiences within their communities to encourage engagement, positive behaviors, and productivity. Bunchball offers features such as missions, badges, leaderboards, and points to motivate users to participate and contribute to the community. The platform also provides analytics and reporting capabilities to track the effectiveness of the gamification efforts.

Based on the extracted parts of the document, it appears that Bunchball was used by some customers for gamification purposes within their Jive communities. However, there are also mentions of discontinuation of Bunchball integration and the need to remove related content. It is unclear from the provided information whether Bunchball is still actively supported and maintained by Jive.

In terms of success with Bunchball, some users have reported positive outcomes, such as increased activity and engagement in their communities. They attribute their success to careful planning, setting clear objectives, creating appealing rewards, launching with a big splash, and continuously monitoring and adjusting the gamification program. It is important to customize the gamification experience to align with the organization's culture and community objectives.

Regarding updates and support for Bunchball, the information is limited. There are mentions of updates for Jive and Bunchball services, but it is unclear how frequently Bunchball specifically is updated for use with Jive. It is recommended to consult with Jive or Bunchball support for the most up-to-date information on updates and support.

In summary, Bunchball is a gamification platform that can be integrated with Jive to create engaging experiences within communities. It offers features such as missions, badges, and points to motivate users. Success with Bunchball depends on careful planning, customization, and continuous monitoring. The availability of updates and support for Bunchball integration with Jive may require further clarification from Jive or Bunchball support.

question: hey what are people talking about
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 June, 2021, here is the answer:
People are talking about various topics in the extracted parts of the document. Here are some of the main discussions:

1. **Uncivil comments in articles**: There is a discussion about how uncivil comments in an article can polarize and distort readers' perception of a news story. The question raised is whether the benefits of comments outweigh the risks.

2. **Social norms and social integration**: There is a question about how social norms will evolve as social integration becomes more embedded across multiple devices. The discussion revolves around the impact of social integration on social norms.

3. **Communicating about a project using email vs. Jive**: The discussion focuses on presenting a classic example of how to communicate about a project using email and Jive. The question raised is how to explain what Jive is and what it can be used for in a short amount of time.

4. **Singing together and human connection**: There is a reflection on the experience of singing together with strangers and the difficulty of translating the power of touch and human connection to strangers. The discussion explores the reasons behind the hesitation to physically connect with others.

5. **Authority and audience participation**: The discussion revolves around a presenter's use of authority and audience participation during a session. There are different perspectives on whether the approach was appropriate or not.

6. **Explaining Jive in layman's terms**: There is a question about how to explain what Jive is in simple terms to someone who only associates "social" with Facebook and Twitter. The discussion includes suggestions on how to pitch Jive as a better way to work and feel more connected.

7. **Group text messaging and Jive**: There is a mention of an app called Beluga, which is used for group text messaging. The discussion speculates on the possibility of a similar feature being included in the next Jive mobile version.

8. **Graph-based personalization and search**: There is a discussion about the concept of a "People Graph" and its impact on personalization, search, and findability of content. The question raised is what happened to the concept and what the plans are for Jive in this regard.

9. **Strange popup when mentioning people**: There is a mention of a strange new popup that appears when mentioning people. The person asks if anyone else has experienced this issue.

10. **Improvements and feature updates for Jive**: There are discussions about various improvements and feature updates that users would like to see in Jive. These include enhancing collaboration through activity streams, improving content management and cleanup, and providing better reporting and feedback on user ideas.

In summary, the discussions cover a range of topics including the impact of comments on news perception, social norms and integration, communication methods, human connection, authority in presentations, explaining Jive, group text messaging, graph-based personalization, and desired improvements for Jive.

question: what all technologies do you know about
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 26 July, 2017, here is the answer:
I'm sorry, but based on the extracted parts of the document provided, I cannot determine the technologies that are being referred to.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 26 July, 2017, here is the answer:
The latest technologies mentioned in the extracted parts of the document include Internet of Things (IoT), connected devices, robots in medicine, connected self-drive vehicles, mobile internet access, cloud computing, big data, and mobile boom.

The document mentions that Internet of Things (IoT) or connected devices will play a major role in the next fifty years, similar to how personal computers revolutionized the world in the last five decades. It also highlights the innovation in various technical fields, including medicine and transportation.

In the field of medicine, robots are expected to perform more precise and reparable surgical procedures. In transportation, connected self-drive vehicles will communicate with each other to minimize accidents.

The document also discusses the growth of mobile internet access. It states that mobile internet access grew by 30% last year, while global internet access grew by 8%. Mobile now accounts for 15% of all internet traffic, up from 10% a year ago. Mobile traffic as a percentage of internet traffic increases 1.5x year over year and is likely to accelerate. The document also mentions that there is still a lot of space for mobile internet access to grow with increased access to smartphones.

China is highlighted as the world's largest country in terms of internet user numbers. 75% of China's population accesses the internet using mobile devices, while 71% use desktop computers. The document suggests that as affordable Chinese smartphones make their way into lower-level emerging market countries, smartphone growth could see another surge.

Tablets are mentioned as being on the rise, with tablets outselling notebooks and desktop PCs less than three years after the introduction of the iPad. The rise of tablets and smartphones is expected to fuel the demand for internet access in emerging markets.

The document also discusses three technology trends with the biggest impact on companies: mobility, cloud computing, and big data. Mobility is highlighted as providing employees with increased access to information and a sense of employment and freedom. Cloud computing is mentioned as enabling companies to share, store, and consume resources at a lower cost and with greater flexibility. Big data is discussed as providing better information, greater operational efficiency, and helping businesses remain competitive.

In terms of search technologies, the document mentions search engine implementation, consulting, and managed services. It also highlights the use of a content processing framework called Aspire for securely accessing, cleaning, normalizing, and enriching content from across the enterprise. The document states that Search Technologies has a comprehensive range of services that address all aspects of enterprise search systems and web-facing search applications.

Overall, the latest technologies mentioned in the document include Internet of Things (IoT), connected devices, robots in medicine, connected self-drive vehicles, mobile internet access, cloud computing, big data, and the mobile boom. These technologies are expected to have a significant impact on various industries and drive innovation and revenue.

question: What is middleware server in Jive ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 October, 2020, here is the answer:
A **middleware server** in Jive refers to a separate server or virtual machine (VM) that is used to host **node.js** and **Jive SDK** components, apart from the main web application server. This configuration is recommended for developing and hosting apps on-premise in Jive 7.0.2. By separating the node.js and Jive SDK components onto a dedicated server, it helps to ensure better performance and scalability.



The **jive-httpd** service in Jive is an **Apache HTTPD** service name that is configured to work with the **Tomcat** instance running Jive. It is not a separate server, but rather a service that works in conjunction with Apache HTTPD and Tomcat to handle HTTP requests and serve Jive content. The jive-httpd service is specific to Jive and is not directly related to the Apache HTTPD server.



In terms of **middleware** options in Jive, there are a few possibilities. The **Jive iPaaS SDK** allows developers to create integrations to Jive without worrying about middleware, as the integration is hosted in the cloud by Jive. The SDK projects are written in **Java**. Another option is **Built.io Flow**, a cross-service iPaaS that can integrate multiple platform services together. It supports various enterprise technologies and has a list of integrated platforms. Both options provide middleware capabilities for integrating with Jive.



Additionally, Jive add-ons can be built using any web-ready programming language. Jive provides open-source SDKs in different languages, including **Node.js**, **Java SpringBoot**, **iOS**, **Android**, **.NET**, **Ruby**, **Python**, and **GoLang**. These SDKs demonstrate the necessary capabilities for building add-ons in each language. Jive also offers services like **Ngrok** to help expedite the Jive development process.



Regarding the **system requirements** for middleware in Jive, it is recommended to have a dedicated middleware server with sufficient resources. The middleware server should have at least **4 CPUs**, **2+ cores**, **12GB RAM**, and **45GB disk space**. Additionally, a dedicated middleware database is required with **2 CPUs**, **4 cores**, and **45GB disk space**. These specifications are for the Forms and Surveys App and may vary depending on the specific use case.



In summary, a middleware server in Jive refers to a separate server or VM used to host node.js and Jive SDK components. The jive-httpd service is an Apache HTTPD service name configured to work with the Tomcat instance running Jive. Jive provides options like the Jive iPaaS SDK and Built.io Flow for middleware capabilities. Jive add-ons can be built using various programming languages, and Jive offers open-source SDKs for each language. The system requirements for middleware in Jive include dedicated servers with specific CPU, core, RAM, and disk space specifications.

question: what's the latest release of Jive HOP?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 18 May, 2022, here is the answer:
The latest release of Jive HOP is version 9.12. This information was provided by a user named Matt Lashley on August 21, 2020. However, it is important to note that according to a user named Glen Elvis on May 18, 2022, none of the customers relying on Jive provided plugins are able to migrate because newer compatible versions of the plugins have not been released. The user expresses frustration with the lack of communication from Aurea and requests information on when the plugins will be available. It is unclear from the given information whether the plugins mentioned by the user are included in the 9.12 release or if they are separate from it.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 18 May, 2022, here is the answer:
The latest release of Jive Hosted On-Premise (HOP) is version 9.9.1. The release date for this version was February 28, 2022. The build version is 9.9.1_4505_8155eb4. This release includes several fixes and updates to the HOP Core, Cache, EAE-service, and other Jive dependencies. Some of the specific fixes include updating to Log4j 2.17.1, fixing the saving of SAML Metadata in SSO settings, and including additional dependencies to the RHEL8 rpm build configuration. The release also includes updates to the HTTP libraries to support newer video plugins.

Unfortunately, there is no information available about the latest release of Jive HOP beyond version 9.9.1. The document excerpts provided do not mention any releases beyond this version. It is recommended to refer to the official Jive Hosted and On-Premise Release Schedule for the most up-to-date information on future releases of Jive HOP.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided for the question 'what's the latest release of Jive HOP?' are both accurate and provide similar information. However, the search_phrase_answer provides more detailed information about the release, such as the build version, specific fixes, and updates to the HTTP libraries. Therefore, the two answers are somewhat similar.

question: How to create a Jive Add-on?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
To create a Jive Add-on, you can follow these steps:

1. Start by familiarizing yourself with the Jive SDK. The Jive Developers space provides detailed instructions on how to get started in building add-ons. You can also find relevant information on the developers.jivesoftware.com site.

2. Determine the type of add-on you want to create. Jive add-ons can be built manually or automatically using the Jive Node SDK. If you choose to use the Jive Node SDK, you can refer to the "Getting Started > Deploying a Jive Node SDK Project as an Add-On" document for additional details about the process.

3. Install the Jive SDK on your development environment. The installation process may vary depending on your operating system. For example, on Mac, Linux, and Unix systems, you can download Node.js and NPM, and then install the Jive SDK globally using the command "sudo npm install jive-sdk -g". On Windows, you can download Node.js and NPM, and then install the Jive SDK globally using the command "npm install jive-sdk -g".

4. Once the Jive SDK is installed, you can start developing your add-on. The SDK provides examples and templates to help you get started. You can use the Jive-SDK command-line tool to create a new add-on project, build the add-on, and deploy it to your Jive community.

5. To deploy your add-on, create a ZIP file containing the add-on package. The package should include configuration files such as meta.json and definition.json, as well as any necessary icons or resource bundles. You can then upload the ZIP file using the Add-Ons menu option in the Jive UI. The installation process may vary depending on your Jive environment, but typically involves logging in to your Jive environment, navigating to the Add-Ons section, and uploading the ZIP file.

6. Once the add-on is successfully installed, you can use its contents within your Jive community. The add-on may provide custom apps, tiles, streams, external storage frameworks, or other Jive extension types. The specific functionality and configuration options will depend on the type of add-on you created.

It's important to note that Jive add-ons are proprietary to Jive and may not work in other systems such as Liferay. If you want to port Jive functionality to Liferay, you will need to adapt the capabilities to Liferay's portlet structure.

Please note that the information provided is based on the extracted parts of a long document, and there may be additional details or steps that are not included. It is always recommended to refer to the official Jive documentation and resources for the most up-to-date and comprehensive instructions.
search_phrase: Steps to create a Jive Add-on
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
To create a Jive Add-on, you can follow these steps:

1. Install the Jive SDK by installing Node.js and running the command \`npm install -g jive-sdk\`.
2. Create a custom-view HTML tile by running the command \`jive-sdk create tile-app-action\` in the desired folder and updating the \`view.html\` file with your HTML code.
3. Build the add-on by running the command \`jive-sdk build add-on --apphosting="MyTileName"\`.
4. Install the add-on in your Jive instance by going to the Add-ons page in the Jive Admin Console and uploading the \`extension.zip\` file.
5. Add the HTML tile to a page by editing the page, adding a tile, selecting the External Add-ons category, and choosing your custom tile.
6. Save the page and the HTML tile will be displayed.

To update the tile, make changes to the \`view.html\` file and rebuild the add-on using the \`jive-sdk build add-on --apphosting="MyTileName"\` command. Then, upload the new \`extension.zip\` file to the Add-ons page in the Jive Admin Console.

Please note that these steps are based on the information provided in the extracted parts of the document. It is always recommended to refer to the official Jive documentation for the most accurate and up-to-date instructions.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided are very similar, with only slight variations in the instructions given. Both answers provide the same steps for creating a Jive Add-on, and the search_phrase_answer provides additional details on how to update the tile. The only difference is that the search_phrase_answer uses the command `npm install -g jive-sdk` instead of `sudo npm install jive-sdk -g` for Mac, Linux, and Unix systems, and `npm install jive-sdk -g` instead of `npm install jive-sdk -g` for Windows systems. Overall, the two answers are very similar.

question: What is DES API?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Jive Data Export Service (DES) is a service that allows users to export analytics data from their Jive community. It was introduced in the Jive Cloud Fall (2013) release and Jive 7. DES provides access to user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API, which can be used to access the data programmatically, and the DES Explorer, which provides access to the data through a user-friendly web interface.

To access the DES, users need a Jive community (Cloud, Hosted, or On-Premise) that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. The DES Explorer can be accessed directly from the community by going to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, users can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data in CSV format.

It's important to note that the data retrieved from the DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics or Google Analytics, due to differences in data collection methods and time spans. When using data from the DES, it's recommended to compare it only with data from the DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

The DES API has new endpoints for AWS DES, which are different depending on the hosting model and location of the instance. For US customers, the endpoint is "https://api-aws.jivesoftware.com", and for EU customers, the endpoint is "https://api-eu-aws.jivesoftware.com". Authentication for the DES API is done using a client ID and secret.

Overall, the DES API provides a powerful way to access and export analytics data from a Jive community, allowing users to gain insights and perform analysis on user activity.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The new AWS DES API's have new endpoints, but they haven't been announced yet due to an issue with them. Once the issue is fixed and the endpoints are tested, more information will be published. The old DES site is being deprecated and the new Analytics Export page is the new version available for customers migrated to AWS DES. The AWS DES API's will require updated endpoint URLs for API scripts and integrations with DES. The transition time and testing period for the new service is important to ensure that people who have automation in place can be ready and have access to their data. It is also important for customers relying on 411 Labs for report automation. The old DES has incomplete data and the new AWS DES is currently buggy and unusable. The immediate reporting need is to get a CSV report of all Space Followers, but it is not possible due to the issues with the new AWS DES. The new endpoints for AWS DES API's are:
- US Customers: [https://api-aws.jivesoftware.com](https://api-aws.jivesoftware.com)
- EU Customers: [https://api-eu-aws.jivesoftware.com](https://api-eu-aws.jivesoftware.com)
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided are very similar and cover the same topic. The search_phrase_answer provides additional information about the endpoints for AWS DES API's and the transition period for the new service, but the overall content is the same.

question: how is Allianz using Jive?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 08 February, 2018, here is the answer:
Allianz is using Jive for various purposes. One use case mentioned in the extracted parts is that Allianz is using Jive to run online Alumni communities. This allows Alumni professionals to connect with each other and share information and ideas. Another use case mentioned is that Allianz is using Jive for corporate communications, HR policies resource center, and corporate directory. This allows employees to have a voice with a global audience and provides a platform for HR to store and share information that is accessible to everyone but secured based on region. Allianz has also used Jive for gamification purposes, offering prizes to employees who contribute ideas on how social could help them do their job more effectively. Additionally, Jive is being used by Allianz to facilitate collaboration and knowledge sharing across the company, with senior leaders using Jive to connect employees to strategy and reinforce key themes. Overall, Allianz is using Jive to improve communication, collaboration, and knowledge sharing within the organization.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 08 February, 2018, here is the answer:
Allianz is piloting the use of Jive to run online Alumni communities. This is an unusual use of Jive, but it allows Alumni professionals to connect with each other. There are other organizations, such as Bandwidth.com and University of Maryland University College, that also use Jive for their internal instances. However, there are some challenges with using Jive, such as integration issues when changing company names and email addresses.
answer_similarity_reason: Both answers provide similar information about how Allianz is using Jive, with the search_phrase_answer providing additional information about other organizations that use Jive and some of the challenges associated with it.

question: what was in the 9.13 version of jive hop?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 November, 2022, here is the answer:
The 9.13 version of Jive HOP includes the following fixes and improvements:

- JVHOPST-75828: Fixed the inability to insert hyperlinks onto images.
- JVHOPST-75827: Fixed the issue where the application-specific group was blocked and unable to access.
- JVHOPST-75825: Fixed the inability to create custom permissions.
- JVHOPST-75589: Fixed the issue where the Super List tile doesn't work when filtering by tags with spaces.
- JVHOPST-75557: Fixed the issue where 'Spaces' couldn't be deleted due to long-running queries from the event-type-plugin.
- JVHOPST-75493: Fixed the issue where Depot Plugins were not deploying for some customers.
- JVHOPST-75464: Added support for Kaltura New URL Embed Codes in on-prem 9.7.2.
- JVHOPST-75079: Fixed the issue where images in the table column of documents did not preserve the configured width.
- JVHOPST-75059: Fixed the issue where the doc conversion process failed to consistently start with OpenOffice.
- JVHOPST-74894: Fixed the incorrect SBS logging in 9.9.1 and 9.12.0.
- JVHOPST-74821: Fixed the issue where addon installation did not remove unused apps.
- JVHOPST-74806: Fixed the red bar error thrown when editing a Carousel Tile.
- JVHOPST-74722: Fixed the issue where an option couldn't be selected from the "Featured Places" Widget Menu.
- JVHOPST-74274: Fixed the issue of orphaned data in the database after user deletion.
- JVHOPST-74224: Fixed the issue where SBS didn't delete attachments completely when an Event was deleted.
- JVHOPST-75806: Fixed the issue where inbox messages were stuck on loading an item, locking the UI.
- JVHOPST-74173: Updated the 'My Jive Licenses Page' to show 9.12 as the latest version.
- JVHOPST-74041: Fixed the system causing DB deadlocks.
- JVHOPST-73976: Fixed the video plugin not working on low resolutions and web mobile.
- JVHOPST-73975: Fixed the issue where SBS didn't delete attachments completely when a Photo Album or Event was deleted.
- JVHOPST-73958: Fixed the video playback issue on mobile.
- JVHOPST-73912: Fixed the ModerationEvent triggering twice for Blogspot comments.
- JVHOPST-72934: Fixed the issue where the Super list tile did not respect the filter unless the filtered view was refreshed.
- JVHOPST-76041: Added support for Kaltura New URL Embed Codes in on-prem 9.7.2.
- JVHOPST-75969: Fixed the issue where group permission changes were not taking effect immediately.

These are the fixes and improvements included in the 9.13 version of Jive HOP.

question: What is DES ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful way to access and export analytics data from a Jive community. It was introduced in Jive 7.0 and Cloud Fall (2013). DES allows users to access user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API that can be used to access the data programmatically, as well as the DES Explorer, which provides access directly from the community UI.

The DES Explorer is a user-friendly interface that allows users to access analytics information in CSV format through a configurable web interface. Once the CSV is obtained, it can be imported into a BI tool or manipulated within Excel. The DES Explorer was introduced with the Jive Cloud 2019.2.3 release.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics, CMR, Google Analytics, or SiteCatalyst. This is because the methods and time spans for data collection are different. For example, DES uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) for its timezone, while CMRs use the timezone of the community. When using data from DES, it is recommended to only compare it against data from DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users can log in to the community and go to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, they can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview or download analytics data.

The DES has certain requirements, including a Jive community that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. It is also important to note the limitations of DES, such as the maximum number of rows returned in a CSV (10,000) and the maximum file size for downloading historical CSVs (180 MB).

For more information and documentation on DES, users can refer to the provided links in the extracted parts of the document.

The Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful way to access and export analytics data from a Jive community. It was introduced in Jive 7.0 and Cloud Fall (2013) and provides access to user activity data beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API for programmatically accessing the data and the DES Explorer for accessing the data directly from the community UI.

The DES Explorer is a user-friendly interface for accessing analytics information in CSV format. It allows users to import the CSV data into a BI tool or manipulate it within Excel. The DES Explorer was introduced with the Jive Cloud 2019.2.3 release and replaces the outdated API Explorer for PHX and AMS customers.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms like Cloud Analytics, CMR, Google Analytics, or SiteCatalyst. This is because the methods and time spans for data collection are different. DES uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) for its timezone, while CMRs use the timezone of the community. When using data from DES, it is recommended to only compare it against data from DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users can log in to the community and go to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, they can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data.

The DES API has new endpoints for AWS DES, but these endpoints are currently experiencing issues. Once the issues are fixed, the new endpoints will be announced and users will need to update their API scripts and integrations with DES to use the new URL endpoints.

In summary, DES is a powerful tool for accessing and exporting analytics data from a Jive community. It includes the DES Explorer for user-friendly access to the data and its own API for programmatically accessing the data. However, it is important to note that the data retrieved from DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms due to differences in data collection methods and timezones.

question: Add-ons
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 June, 2023, here is the answer:
Add-ons in Jive are service-based extensions that can be installed and managed by non-technical users. They can be used to add functionality to the Jive community by integrating with external services or creating custom UI elements. Add-ons can be installed directly from the Jive user interface or by uploading a zip file containing the configuration settings.

Add-ons can be categorized based on their type, which helps in managing and filtering them in the Jive user interface. They can configure various aspects of Jive, depending on the available adapters. The most important files in an add-on package are the meta.json and definition.json files, which contain the configuration data and schema specific to the add-on type.

Developing add-ons is made easier with the Jive SDK, which provides tools and resources for building and deploying add-ons. The Jive SDK is available for different platforms like Node.js, Java, and .NET. It allows developers to create the necessary endpoints and services for their add-ons. Add-ons can be hosted anywhere as long as Jive can route to the middleware host.

Add-ons can contain custom code in various programming languages, depending on the chosen development platform. They do not require node.js development specifically, but it is recommended for faster development using the Jive SDK. Add-ons can be used in both on-premise and cloud-based Jive instances.

The capabilities of add-ons are not limited to providing pre-packaged functionality like cartridges and tiles. They can also make external web service calls, execute custom business logic, interact with external databases, call Jive APIs, and return custom views to the user. The Jive SDK takes care of the communication between the add-on and Jive, handling authentication and other necessary tasks.

In summary, add-ons in Jive are service-based extensions that can be installed and managed by non-technical users. They can provide various functionalities by integrating with external services and creating custom UI elements. Add-ons can be developed using the Jive SDK, which supports different programming languages. They can be used in both on-premise and cloud-based Jive instances and offer flexibility in terms of customization and functionality.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 02 November, 2021, here is the answer:
Add-ons in Jive are service-based and can be used to provide various functionalities. They are completely service-based and can be implemented using different technologies. The Jive SDK with Node.js is recommended for faster results. However, Add-Ons do not have the same level of Java access that plugins once had and cannot manipulate core Java natively. There is a crude SDK available that shows how to implement some of the end-points using simple Java. Add-Ons can be used by any version of Jive, including on-premise instances.

Add-Ons are used to provide configuration settings that Jive uses to call web services and integrate the data into the UI. They can contain apps that integrate the data into the UI in various ways, such as cartridges, tiles, or OpenSocial apps. The services that the apps call can be hosted anywhere, as long as Jive can route to the middleware host. While hosting on Heroku with Node.js is recommended for infrastructure and quick spin-up, services can be hosted on-premise as well. The format of the add-on, including URL structure, parameters, and HTTP methods, is not explicitly documented, but the Jive SDK takes care of the boilerplate code and handshakes.

To alter the experience within the application, custom themes can be created that pull data from an add-on. However, there is no specific documentation on what parts of the profile page can be altered using add-ons. The capabilities of add-ons are not limited to providing pre-packaged bits of functionality like cartridges or tiles. They can be used to make external web service calls, execute custom business logic, interact with external databases, and call Jive APIs. The data can be formatted in any way that is suitable for the application.

In summary, add-ons in Jive are service-based and can be implemented using different technologies. They can be used to provide various functionalities and integrate data into the UI. Add-ons can be used by any version of Jive, including on-premise instances. They do not have the same level of Java access as plugins and cannot manipulate core Java natively. The Jive SDK with Node.js is recommended for faster development. Add-ons can be used to make external web service calls, execute custom business logic, interact with external databases, and call Jive APIs. The data can be formatted in any suitable way.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided are mostly similar, with the search_phrase_answer providing additional information on the capabilities of add-ons and the development process. The search_phrase_answer also provides more specific information on the types of add-ons and how they can be used in different Jive instances.

question: What is the latest version of Jive?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 May, 2021, here is the answer:
The latest version of Jive is **30.7.28**. This information was provided in a thread by Sarah O'Meara, who mentioned that the latest version can be found at the following link: [Jive for Office/Outlook 30.7.28](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/thread/308711). It is important to note that this information was provided on September 21, 2017, so there may have been newer versions released since then.

search_phrase: What is CURL and how does it work?
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 04 August, 2020, here is the answer:
CURL is a command line tool that is used to consume web services. It is commonly used to make HTTP requests and interact with REST APIs. CURL allows users to send requests to a server and receive responses. It supports various HTTP methods such as GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE.

To use CURL, you need to provide the URL of the API endpoint you want to interact with, along with any necessary headers or parameters. CURL can be used to send data to the server, retrieve data from the server, or perform other operations such as file uploads.

In the provided document, there are several mentions of CURL in the context of using the Jive REST API. However, it is important to note that CURL is not the recommended or best way to use the Jive REST API. The document suggests using other methods such as WebClient or HttpWebRequest in C# for interacting with the Jive REST API.

In one of the threads, there is a request for examples on how to use CURL with the Jive image endpoint service. Unfortunately, the document does not provide any specific examples for using CURL with the image endpoint. It mentions that there is an example on how to use CURL in general, but it does not explain how it would work with the image endpoint.

In another thread, there is a request for examples on how to use CURL with the Jive REST services in PHP. The document suggests using CURL functions in PHP to interact with the Jive REST API. However, it also mentions that the provided example does not work and does not provide any alternative solution.

Overall, the document provides limited information about CURL and its usage with the Jive REST API. It is recommended to refer to the official Jive REST API documentation for more detailed and accurate information on how to use CURL or other methods to interact with the Jive REST API.

question: what is aurea51?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 6 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 29 March, 2021, here is the answer:
**Aurea** is a global business that specializes in accelerating digital transformation through the use of a software library. Since its launch in 2012, Aurea has successfully completed 14 enterprise software business mergers and acquisitions. To learn more about Aurea's mission and the acquisitions they have made, you can visit their website at [www.aurea.com/about](https://www.aurea.com/about) and [www.aurea.com/our-acquisitions](https://www.aurea.com/our-acquisitions).

The renewal process with Aurea is an easy and automated process. It begins 120 days before your scheduled renewal date. You will need to confirm your company contact information, and Aurea will send you a renewal quote approximately 90 to 80 days before your maintenance is due to expire. You can find answers to commonly asked questions and chat with a renewal representative on the AureaWorks Customer Renewal space at [AureaWorks Customer Renewal space](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/community/customer-hub/customer-renewals/pages/overview). To ensure continuation of your service, you must return the signed agreement via e-signature 60 to 30 days prior to renewal. The signed agreement must be received no later than 30 days prior to the maintenance expiration date.

To update your company name and other contact information, you can fill out the [Update Company Profile form](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSdxP-6pYBwAav0PhDg7rpQKPrtkXc-_CvtOTuRpgu4pOB3oyA%2Fviewform).

To update your billing address and other contact information, you can fill out the [Update Company Profile form](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fforms%2Fd%2Fe%2F1FAIpQLSdxP-6pYBwAav0PhDg7rpQKPrtkXc-_CvtOTuRpgu4pOB3oyA%2Fviewform).

If you want to increase or decrease the number of licenses you have, you can fill out a [contact form](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Fcontent.aurea.com%2Fproduct-info-request-form%2F) and an Aurea Sales Representative will contact you as soon as possible.

If you need a copy of your customer contract, you can ask a live chat representative for assistance at [ask a live chat representative](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Faurea.drift.click%2Faurearenewalchat).

To find out when your current contract expires, you can refer to your signed customer agreement or ask a live chat representative for assistance at [ask a live chat representative](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Faurea.drift.click%2Faurearenewalchat).

The amount you paid last year can be found on your signed customer agreement. You can also ask a live chat representative for assistance at [ask a live chat representative](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Faurea.drift.click%2Faurearenewalchat).

Aurea does not allow suggestions or revisions to their standard terms and conditions. If you have further questions, you can work with your sales account executive or chat with a renewal representative at [chat with a renewal representative](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Faurea.drift.click%2Faurearenewalchat).

Aurea provides W9 forms that can be found in the [Renewal Document Repository](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/community/customer-hub/customer-renewals/content?filterID=contentstatus%5Bpublished%5D~category%5Bsole-source-letter%5D). If you can't find what you're looking for, you can chat with a renewal representative at [chat with a renewal representative](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Faurea.drift.click%2Faurearenewalchat).

To access the Sole Source Letters, you can visit the [Renewal Document Repository](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/community/customer-hub/customer-renewals/content?filterID=contentstatus%5Bpublished%5D~category%5Bsole-source-letter%5D). If you can't find what you're looking for, you can chat with a renewal representative at [chat with a renewal representative](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/external-link.jspa?url=https%3A%2F%2Faurea.drift.click%2Faurearenewalchat).

To submit a Vendor Registration Form, you can start a new chat with a renewal representative and upload the document using the paperclip icon in the chat window.

Unfortunately, there is no information available about Aurea's ability to fill out an Automated Clearing House (ACH) form.

question: What is bunchball?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 October, 2021, here is the answer:
Bunchball is a gamification platform that was integrated with Jive, a community and collaboration software. However, based on the provided information, it is unclear whether Bunchball is still actively supported and connected to Jive. In a thread from 2021, it was mentioned that Bunchball is no longer supported and should be removed. On the other hand, in a thread from 2014, it was mentioned that there are still customers using Bunchball. Therefore, it is unclear whether Bunchball is still available for integration with Jive.

It is worth noting that Bunchball was used to introduce gamification elements in Jive communities. Gamification involves using game mechanics and techniques to engage and motivate users in non-game contexts. Bunchball's missions, badges, and events were used to encourage positive and productive behavior in Jive communities. The success of gamification in Jive communities varied depending on factors such as the organization's culture, community objectives, and the careful design and implementation of the gamification system.

To achieve success with Bunchball or any gamification system, it is important to carefully design the game to align with the organization's culture and community objectives. Setting the tone from the start, emphasizing quality by rewarding recognition from others, and launching with a big splash can help drive engagement and sustained participation. Planning for the long haul and continuously monitoring for cheaters are also important aspects of a successful gamification strategy.

It is unclear how often Bunchball is updated for use with Jive based on the provided information. In a thread from 2015, it was mentioned that the Bunchball service has constant minor updates, but the Bunchball admin UI and major service releases had not been updated recently. It is recommended to consult with Jive or Bunchball support for the most up-to-date information on updates and new features.

In summary, Bunchball is a gamification platform that was integrated with Jive to introduce game mechanics and techniques in Jive communities. The success of gamification in Jive communities varied depending on various factors. However, it is unclear whether Bunchball is still actively supported and connected to Jive based on the provided information. It is recommended to consult with Jive or Bunchball support for more information on the current status of Bunchball integration with Jive.

Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 October, 2021, here is the answer:
**Bunchball** is a gamification platform that was integrated with Jive, a collaboration software. It allowed organizations to incentivize and reward user engagement and participation within their Jive communities. However, based on the provided information, it seems that Bunchball is no longer supported and connected to Jive. The content related to Bunchball should be removed as it is no longer relevant.

In one of the threads, Michelle Gantt mentioned that there are still a few hosted or on-prem customers who use Bunchball, which is why the content hasn't been archived yet. However, it is acknowledged that Bunchball integration is no longer supported, even for those customers. Therefore, it is recommended to remove the Bunchball content.

In another thread, Dan Katz clarified that the Bunchball Wiki is reserved for customers using the Nitro Platform, which can be licensed by Jive customers to expand the systems they are gamifying outside of only Jive. If someone is interested in exploring the capabilities of the Nitro platform, they should contact their Jive account manager, who will initiate conversations with the Bunchball team.

Overall, it can be concluded that Bunchball was a gamification platform integrated with Jive, but it is no longer supported and connected to Jive. The content related to Bunchball should be removed, and if someone is interested in gamification beyond Jive, they can explore the Nitro platform through licensing and discussions with the Bunchball team.

question: Mega Menu Add-on
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 2 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
The Mega Menu Add-on allows users to create and configure a mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings and elements to create a visually appealing and user-friendly navigation experience.

To access the Mega Menu, users can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, they can select the "Edit" option to make changes to the menu.

The menu settings can be customized in the Theme page by adding custom CSS. Users can add custom CSS to hide certain elements or modify the position of the menu. After making changes, users can save the theme.

To configure the Mega Menu Add-On, users can go to the configuration page via the URL: /apps/mega-menu-add-on. From there, they can configure various settings such as the menu behavior, effects, speed, line height, logo, cache time, position, and sticky behavior.

The Mega Menu Add-On also supports visibility rules, which allow users to control the visibility of menu items based on user profiles. Users can create visibility rules and specify conditions for when the menu items should be visible. These rules can be managed and edited in the configuration panel.

Users can also create dropdown menus within the mega menu. They can add sub-menu items, edit their details, and manage the menu items by using icons for editing, adding, and deleting. The menu items can be arranged by dragging and dropping within the list.

The Mega Menu Add-On also provides options for translation in different languages. Users can create translations for the main menu items and specify the language, title, and target URL for each translation.

To export or import the configuration settings of the Mega Menu Add-On, users can use the Export/Import feature. They can export the settings as a text file and import them to another environment or instance.

The installation process of the Mega Menu Add-On involves creating user groups for admins and editors, setting system properties, uploading the add-on package, configuring user group settings, and syncing files. The detailed installation steps are provided in the document.

In summary, the Mega Menu Add-On provides users with the ability to create and configure a customizable mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings, visibility rules, translations, and dropdown menus. The add-on enhances the navigation experience and allows for easy management of menu items.

The Mega Menu Add-On allows users to create and configure a mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings and elements to create a visually appealing and user-friendly navigation experience.

To access the Mega Menu, users can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, they can select the "Edit" option to make changes to the menu.

The Mega Menu Add-On also supports visibility rules, which allow users to control the visibility of menu items based on user profiles. Users can also create dropdown menus within the mega menu. They can add sub-menu items, edit their details, and manage the menu items. Dropdown menus can be created in both grid and vertical tab styles.

The Mega Menu Add-On also provides options for exporting and importing the configuration settings, allowing users to easily transfer their settings to another environment or instance.

Overall, the Mega Menu Add-On provides a comprehensive solution for creating and configuring a mega menu in Jive, allowing users to enhance the navigation experience for their community.

question: What is community on Jive ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 June, 2021, here is the answer:
The Jive Community is a living and breathing platform designed for customers and partners of Jive to collaborate, seek answers, and receive support for their own communities. It serves as a knowledge repository and facilitates communication among individuals with similar interests or roles. The community is intended to foster engagement and provide a platform for sharing resources, course materials, and assignments. It also allows participants to continue conversations and collaborations beyond the classroom setting. The Jive Community is not limited to specific software products or teams, but rather encompasses a wide range of topics and roles. It aims to connect individuals and provide them with the knowledge and support they need to excel in their respective fields. The community is built on Java and .Net technologies, and it offers various features and functionalities to enhance user experience and facilitate seamless communication. Overall, the Jive Community is a valuable platform for networking, knowledge sharing, and professional development.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 October, 2019, here is the answer:
Jive is a social collaboration tool for business that allows people to connect, share ideas, and collaborate across functional areas. It breaks down silos and facilitates innovation, information sharing, and problem-solving. Jive is like a cross between a social network and enterprise tools, providing a platform for socializing project and document management, and knowledge sharing. It is designed to increase productivity, improve effectiveness and efficiency, and foster engagement and connection within the organization. Jive is a comprehensive platform that replaces multiple tools with seamless functionality, making it easier for employees to find information, connect with others, and work together. It also offers features like real-time activity streams, convenience through integration with other tools like Outlook, and gamification to make collaboration fun and engaging. Overall, Jive is a powerful tool that helps organizations thrive by promoting collaboration, innovation, and knowledge sharing.

question: what is DES
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful way to access and export analytics data from a Jive community. It was introduced in Jive 7.0 and Cloud Fall (2013) and provides access to user activity data beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API for programmatically accessing the data and the DES Explorer for accessing the data directly from the community UI.

The DES Explorer is a user-friendly interface for accessing analytics information in CSV format. It allows users to import the CSV data into a BI tool or manipulate it within Excel. The DES Explorer was introduced with the Jive Cloud 2019.2.3 release and replaces the outdated API Explorer for PHX and AMS customers.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms like Cloud Analytics, CMR, Google Analytics, or SiteCatalyst. This is because the methods and time spans for data collection are different. DES uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) for its timezone, while CMRs use the timezone of the community. When using data from DES, it is recommended to only compare it against data from DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users can log in to the community and go to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, they can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data.

The DES API has new endpoints for AWS DES, but they have not been announced yet due to an ongoing issue. Once the issue is fixed, more information will be provided. It is important to note that scripts and integrations using the V2 Jive Data Export Service may need to be updated with the new API endpoints once they are working.

In terms of requirements, users need a Jive community (Cloud, Hosted, or On-Premise) that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. Access to the DES Explorer does not require a client ID and secret.

There are some limitations to be aware of when using DES. The maximum number of rows returned in a CSV is limited to 10,000, so pagination should be used for larger datasets. Files larger than 180 MB cannot be downloaded from the Historical CSVs tab. Exporting data with the DES Explorer is also subject to the Jive Analytics Data Retention Policy.

For more information and documentation on DES, users can refer to the provided links in the extracted parts of the document.

question: what was in the latest Jive HOP release?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 October, 2020, here is the answer:
The latest Jive HOP release is not mentioned in the provided extracted parts of the document.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 17 May, 2022, here is the answer:
The latest Jive HOP release is version 9.9.1. It was released on February 28, 2022. The build version is 9.9.1_4505_8155eb4. This release includes several fixes and updates to the Hosted/On-Prem Core, such as updating HOP Core, Cache, EAE-service, and other Jive dependencies to Log4j 2.17.1. It also includes fixes for saving SAML Metadata in SSO settings, including additional dependencies to RHEL8 rpm build configuration, and updating HTTP libraries to support newer video plugin.

For more information about this release, you can refer to the Jive Hosted and On-Premise Release Schedule at [https://thrive.ignitetech.com/docs/DOC-260096](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/docs/DOC-260096).
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided are similar in that they both provide an answer to the same question. However, the search_phrase_answer provides more detailed information on the latest Jive HOP release, including the version, release date, and additional fixes and updates.

question: who is in the professional services team?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 February, 2018, here is the answer:
The professional services team at Jive is comprised of smaller teams specializing in various fields such as engineering and consulting. They are dedicated to working with customers to help them successfully implement Jive and meet their business goals. Whether customers need assistance with training, configuration, implementation, designing the Jive UI, purchasing add-ons, data migration services, or advice on content, SEO, or communications consulting, the professional services team can provide the necessary support. The team is equipped with the right expertise to handle different requirements and ensure a successful implementation.

To contact the professional services team for more information or any questions, customers can leave a comment below the Jive Professional Services space or reach out to their account representative. The team is available to provide detailed information about the services offered and address any inquiries customers may have.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 April, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive Professional Services (PS) is a department within Jive that consists of smaller teams specializing in various fields such as engineering and consulting. The PS team is dedicated to working with customers to help them successfully implement Jive and meet their business goals. They offer assistance in areas such as training, configuration, implementation, designing the Jive UI, purchasing add-ons, data migration services, and content, SEO, and communications consulting. The PS team is equipped with the right expertise to provide support and guidance in these areas.



The Aurea Professional Services space is a platform where users can access best practices, thought leadership blogs, and interact with the Professional Services team. It serves as a hub for sharing experiences and starting meaningful conversations about Jive. Whether users work with the PS team, one of their partners, or on their own, the space provides valuable resources and opportunities for collaboration and communication.



To get more information about Jive Professional Services and their offerings, users can reach out to the PS team through the comments section or contact their account representative. They can inquire about the services provided by Jive PS and ask any questions they may have.



Unfortunately, there is no specific information provided about the cost of Jive licenses or the number of users that can be registered. It is recommended to contact Jive directly or consult with a sales team to get accurate and up-to-date information regarding licensing and user registration.



In terms of handling groups that show resistance to using Jive, there are various approaches that can be taken. One approach is to identify and address the concerns of the resistant groups, such as addressing security settings for sharing sensitive data. It can be helpful to showcase examples of successful implementations within similar organizations and highlight the benefits of using Jive for collaboration and communication. Additionally, providing training and support to help users navigate and utilize the platform effectively can also help overcome resistance. It is important to have an advocate within the resistant group who can champion the use of Jive and provide ongoing support and guidance.



Overall, Jive Professional Services offers a range of services and expertise to help customers successfully implement Jive and meet their business goals. The Aurea Professional Services space provides a platform for accessing resources and interacting with the Professional Services team. For more information and specific inquiries, users can contact the PS team or their account representative.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided are very similar in content, with the search_phrase_answer providing more detailed information and updated information on the latest documents and services offered by Jive Professional Services. The search_phrase_answer also provides more information on how to contact the Professional Services team and how to handle groups that may be resistant to using Jive.
