question: What is the purpose of this community?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 February, 2021, here is the answer:
The purpose of this community is to serve as an intranet and collaboration space for projects and working parties. It is used to share corporate knowledge, facilitate collaboration, and connect individuals within the organization. The community aims to provide value to its members by offering a platform for communication, information sharing, and problem-solving. It also encourages engagement and participation through various activities such as quests, points, badges, and contests. The community managers strive to create a sense of belonging and foster personal relationships among members to enhance collaboration and knowledge sharing. The community's goal is to increase engagement and adoption by addressing barriers, providing relevant and valuable content, and promoting the benefits of active participation.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 June, 2021, here is the answer:
The purpose of this community is to serve as an intranet and collaboration space for projects and working parties within the organization. It is designed to facilitate knowledge sharing, collaboration, and communication among employees. The community aims to create a culture of transparency, trust, relationship, sharing, and collaboration. It encourages employees to actively engage and participate in discussions, seek answers to their questions, and contribute to the overall success of the community.

One of the main challenges in driving engagement within the community is getting users to initially join and set up their accounts. Another challenge is creating valuable content and processes that keep users coming back. The community relies on the members to determine what they find valuable, and it is important to understand their needs and motivations. Gamification, such as quests, points, and badges, can be used to incentivize engagement and demonstrate the value of the community. However, it is important to note that not everyone is motivated by points, and the effectiveness of gamification may vary among individuals.

To increase engagement, it is suggested to create quests or scavenger hunts that guide users to relevant content and places within the community. This can help users familiarize themselves with the platform and encourage active participation. Additionally, sending out questions and rewarding users for finding the answers can promote engagement and knowledge sharing. Creating polls and gathering feedback from the community can also be a valuable way to involve members and make them feel heard. It is important to make the tasks and activities fun, relevant, and aligned with the corporate culture to ensure maximum participation.

Building personal relationships with community members is also emphasized as a way to open doors and encourage engagement. Face-to-face interactions and creating connections with individuals can help establish trust and encourage collaboration. It is important to have a plan B in case engagement is low or pre-work is not completed, as some users may be busy or have other priorities. Overall, it is crucial to continuously monitor and adapt engagement strategies based on the needs and preferences of the community members.

In summary, the purpose of this community is to serve as an intranet and collaboration space for projects and working parties. The community aims to facilitate knowledge sharing, collaboration, and communication among employees. To drive engagement, it is important to understand the needs and motivations of the members and create valuable content and processes. Gamification, quests, scavenger hunts, polls, and personal relationships can all be effective strategies to increase engagement. Continuous monitoring and adaptation of engagement strategies are essential for the success of the community.

question: What is refresh token in Jive ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 July, 2021, here is the answer:
The refresh token in Jive is used to request a new access token once the current one expires. When a user authenticates with Jive, they receive an access token and a refresh token. The access token is used to access resources directly, while the refresh token is used to obtain a new access token when needed.

By default, the access token in Jive is valid for 48 hours from issuance. If a request is made with an expired access token, it will result in a 401 response code. The refresh token, on the other hand, has a default lifespan of 10 years. This means that it can be used to request new access tokens for a long period of time.

To make REST API calls with the access token, it needs to be included in the "Authorization: Bearer" header. For example, a curl command to create a new discussion would look like this:

\`\`\`
curl -X POST -i -H 'Authorization: Bearer qwergqefq5bad5fp03rwjwzzyh3da8vyha92wm6f.t' -H 'Content-Type: application/json' 'https://your.jive.commmunity.com/api/core/v3/contents' -d '{ "type": "discussion", "content": { "type": "text/html", "text":"Starting a discussion"}, "subject": "A new OAUTH discussion"}'
\`\`\`

When the access token expires, the refresh token can be used to request a new access token. This can be done by making a POST request to the token endpoint with the refresh token, client ID, and client secret. Here is an example of a curl request to request a new access token:

\`\`\`
curl -u ':' -d 'grant_type=refresh_token&refresh_token=' https://your.jive.community.com/oauth2/token
\`\`\`

Jive also provides the ability to set the expiration settings for both the access and refresh tokens. By default, the access token expires in 48 hours and the refresh token expires in 10 years. These settings can be changed in the advanced settings of the Jive add-on.

Revoking access to a previously granted client or application can be done through the Jive UI or by performing a REST API call. In the Jive UI, access can be revoked by going to the Apps Management section and revoking access to a specific application. This will revoke both the access and refresh tokens, requiring the user to grant access again using the Authorization Code Grant method. Revoking access through the REST API involves retrieving a list of authorizations given by a person and then deleting the specific grant.

In summary, the refresh token in Jive is used to request a new access token when the current one expires. The access token is used to access resources directly, and the refresh token has a long lifespan of 10 years. The expiration settings for both tokens can be adjusted, and access can be revoked through the Jive UI or REST API.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 July, 2021, here is the answer:
The refresh token in Jive is used to obtain a new access token without having to go through the full "OAuth dance" again. To use the refresh token, you can make a POST request to YOUR-JIVE-URL/oauth2/token with the following parameters:
- refresh_token: _your refresh token_
- grant_type: refresh_token
- client_id: _your client id_
- client_secret: _your client secret_

This will give you a brand new access token. It is important to note that the access token obtained using the refresh token will also have an expiration time, typically set to 48 hours. Once the access token expires, you will need to use the refresh token again to request another access token.

To make REST API calls using the access token, you need to include the access token in the Authorization header as "Bearer ". For example, you can use the access token to create a new discussion by making a POST request to the Jive REST API endpoint.

If you want to request another access token using the refresh token, you can use the same POST request to YOUR-JIVE-URL/oauth2/token with the refresh token and client credentials. Jive will respond with a new access token and refresh token, which you can use for further API calls.

It is important to note that the access token obtained using the refresh token will also have an expiration time, typically set to 48 hours. Once the access token expires, you will need to use the refresh token again to request another access token.

To revoke access to an application or view the applications that have been granted access, you can use the Jive UI or perform a REST API call. In the Jive UI, you can go to the Apps Management section and revoke access to specific applications. This will revoke both the access token and refresh token, requiring the user to grant access again using the Authorization Code Grant method.

Alternatively, you can use the Jive REST API to revoke access. You can retrieve a list of authorizations given by a person using the Authorization entity endpoint, and then delete a specific grant using the grant ID. This will also revoke the access and refresh tokens associated with that grant.

In terms of token expiration settings, you can change the expiration time for both the access token and refresh token. By default, the access token expires in 48 hours and the refresh token has a lifespan of 10 years. These settings can be configured in the Jive UI under the Advanced Settings of the Manage Add-ons section.

It is important to note that the behavior of tokens and their expiration can vary depending on the specific implementation and configuration of Jive. It is recommended to refer to the Jive documentation and consult with Jive support for specific details and guidance on token management and expiration in your Jive instance.

question: What is DES ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful way to access and export analytics data from a Jive community. It was introduced in Jive 7.0 and Cloud Fall (2013). DES allows users to access user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports (CMR). DES includes its own API that can be used to access the data programmatically, as well as the DES Explorer, which provides access directly from the community UI.

The DES Explorer is a user-friendly interface that allows users to access analytics information in CSV format through a configurable web interface. Once the CSV is obtained, it can be imported into a BI tool or manipulated within Excel. The DES Explorer was introduced with the Jive Cloud 2019.2.3 release.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics, CMR, Google Analytics, or SiteCatalyst. This is because the methods and time spans for data collection are different. For example, DES uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) for its timezone, while CMRs use the timezone of the community. When using data from DES, it is recommended to only compare it against data from DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users can log in to the community and go to "Your avatar > Analytics Export". From there, they can change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data.

DES has certain requirements, including a Jive community that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. It is also important to note the limitations of DES, such as the maximum number of rows returned in a CSV (10,000) and the maximum file size for downloading historical CSVs (180 MB).

For more information and documentation on DES, users can refer to the provided links in the extracted parts of the document.

question: What is the Data Extraction Service and how can I use it?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
The Jive Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful tool that allows users to extract analytics data from their Jive community. It provides access to user activity data that goes beyond what is available in Cloud Analytics or Community Manager Reports. The DES includes its own API, which can be used to access the data programmatically, as well as the DES Explorer, which provides a user-friendly interface for data export.

To use the DES, users can access the DES Explorer directly from their Jive community. The DES Explorer allows users to change the date range, apply activity filters, and preview and download analytics data in CSV format. The exported data can then be imported into a BI tool or manipulated within Excel.

It is important to note that the data retrieved from the DES may not match up with data from other analytics platforms, such as Cloud Analytics or Google Analytics, due to differences in data collection methods and time spans. Therefore, it is recommended to compare data from the DES only with data from the DES to ensure accurate comparisons.

To access the DES Explorer, users need a Jive community (Cloud, Hosted, or On-Premise) that uses Cloud Analytics and a user account with the Manage System, Manage Community, or Full Access permissions. No client ID and secret are required to access the DES Explorer.

The DES Explorer has some limitations, such as a maximum of 10,000 rows returned in a CSV and a maximum file size of 180 MB for downloading historical CSVs. The data exported with the DES Explorer is subject to the Jive Analytics Data Retention Policy.

For more information on how to use the DES Explorer, including how to filter the data and download CSVs, users can refer to the Jive Cloud Analytics Community Manager Guide. The guide provides detailed documentation on the DES Explorer and its various features.

In summary, the Jive Data Export Service (DES) is a powerful tool that allows users to extract analytics data from their Jive community. It provides a user-friendly interface, the DES Explorer, for data export and allows users to change the date range, apply activity filters, and download analytics data in CSV format. The exported data can be used for further analysis or integration with other tools.

question: What is expiry time in Jive ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The expiry time in Jive refers to the ability to set expiration dates for content using content metadata. This feature allows authors to receive emails in advance of the expiration date, giving them the opportunity to update the content and prevent it from expiring. The general idea is to have a lightweight app or add-on that can be used in Jive 6.0.1+ and Jive 7. The estimated development time for this customization is 3-4 weeks. The cost of developing the app/add-on and running the service is around $20K, which can be split between the customers who back the project. The more backers there are, the lower the cost per customer. The goal is to convince Jive to include this functionality in a future version if it proves to be useful and widely used.

In terms of session expiration and login, Jive has a system property called "login.rememberme.disabled" that can be set to true to force users to reauthenticate every time their session expires. The session expiration time is controlled by the "auth.lifetime" property, which defaults to 30 minutes. However, when using Single Sign-On (SSO), the process is more complicated. When a user logs in via SSO, they will have a session created in Jive that is valid for the specified auth.lifetime. Once that period expires, Jive will send the user back to the SSO provider to log in again. The SAML settings include a Maximum Authentication Age to prevent users from staying logged in too long. If the SSO server responds with a "valid" statement that is older than the Maximum Authentication Age, the response is rejected on the Jive side, and the user receives a login error. To work around this issue, the user can visit the SSO side, log out manually, and then log back in to refresh the authentication statement.

Regarding password expiration, Jive does not have built-in functionality for expiring passwords for non-federated users. However, it is possible to customize and develop this feature. One option is to set a password expiration period and redirect users to a page to reset their password when it expires. Another option is to use Active Directory with multiple domain access to handle different user setups.

For OAuth2 tokens, Jive provides the ability to revoke tokens and set expiration date/time intervals for both access and refresh tokens in the UI. Tokens can be revoked using the OAuth Client Management feature.

In terms of the Jive for Mobile app, users may experience OAuth Token Expired errors if they don't use the app frequently. In this case, they can manually log in again by entering the correct community URL. It is not currently possible to configure the app to automatically try logging in again if the OAuth Token has expired.

Lastly, if you need to update the copyright date in Jive, you can make arrangements to advance the date to the desired year. This can be done by modifying the copyright message in the Jive pages.

Please note that the information provided is based on the extracted parts of the document, and there may be additional details or updates not included in the given information.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 22 March, 2023, here is the answer:
The expiry time in Jive refers to the ability to set expiration dates for content using content metadata. This feature allows authors to receive emails in advance of the expiration date to update and prevent the content from expiring. The estimated time to develop this feature as an app/add-on for Jive 6.0.1+ and Jive 7 is 3-4 weeks. The cost of developing the app/add-on and running the service is estimated to be around $20,000, which can be split among the customers who back the project. The more backers there are, the lower the cost per customer. The goal is to convince Jive to include this functionality in a future version if it proves to be useful and widely used.

There is no built-in functionality in Jive for expiring passwords for non-federated users. However, there is a request for a workaround or a custom solution to expire passwords after 60 days. Some users have mentioned the need for customization and development to achieve this functionality. It is suggested to work with a developer or customize the base app to meet specific requirements.

In Jive Cloud instances, the authentication context lifetime is set to 12 hours by default and cannot be manually changed. This limitation applies to Cloud environments, and there is no option to increase the authentication context lifetime.

In Jive 5, it is not possible to change the timeout message for edit sessions when they expire. The message displayed to users when an edit session times out cannot be customized.

The copyright date displayed at the bottom of each Jive page can be updated manually. In this case, the request was to advance the copyright date to 2016. This can be done by modifying the copyright message in the Jive configuration.

Jive Cloud uses a default view of 180 days for activity/inbox content history. This means that the activity history displayed in Jive Cloud is limited to the past 180 days.

There is a discussion about a mission that remains with an expiration banner even after the expiration date. It is mentioned that the banner does not go away on its own, and there is a request to either remove the banner or keep it to indicate that the deadline was missed.

Regarding user logins and session expiration, it is possible to configure Jive to require users to log in every day by setting the system property "login.rememberme.disabled" to true. This forces users to reauthenticate every time their session expires. The session expiration time is controlled by the "auth.lifetime" property, which defaults to 30 minutes. However, when using SSO, the process becomes more complex. When a user logs in via SSO, they have a session created in Jive that is valid for a certain period. Once that period expires, Jive sends the user back to the SSO provider to log in again. The SAML settings include a Maximum Authentication Age to prevent users from staying logged in too long. If the SAML response from the SSO server is older than the Maximum Authentication Age, the response is rejected, and the user receives a login error. To work around this issue, the user can manually log out from the SSO side and then log back in to refresh the authentication statement. Alternatively, clearing cookies can also help refresh the authentication statement.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided are very similar and cover the same topics. The search_phrase_answer provides more detailed information about the topics discussed in the original answer, such as authentication context lifetime, password expiration, OAuth2 tokens, and copyright date. The search_phrase_answer also provides additional information about mission expiration banners and user logins and session expiration.

question: Mega Menu
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 4 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
Yes, it is possible to use a mega menu in Jive. The mega menu feature allows for advanced navigation configuration and customization. To access the mega menu, you can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, you can edit the mega menu by selecting the "Edit" option on the top left. The mega menu settings can be configured in an editable mode, and you can exit the edit mode by clicking on "Cancel" on the top right.

The mega menu settings include various options such as defining the desired menu behavior (hover or click), selecting an effect for the panel/dropdown (none, fade, slide, push), setting the speed of panel rendering, defining the line height, adding a shadow, specifying a logo image file and target link, setting the cache time for the mega menu structure, and choosing the position of the mega menu (above, below, or merged with the standard Jive header bar). Additionally, there is an option to make the mega menu sticky to fix or scroll it.

The mega menu can be customized further by configuring settings for the general settings, logo, main navigation, top-level menu items, dropdown panel, grid (column), sub-menu items (level 2), and third-level menu items. Each of these settings has its own set of options and configurations, such as defining font styles, background colors, padding, borders, and more.

To export or import the configuration of the mega menu, you can use the Export/Import feature. This feature allows you to save and transfer the configured settings to another environment or instance. You can also save previous configurations as backups using this feature.

The mega menu add-on has undergone several updates and improvements over time. The release notes provide detailed information about the changes and fixes made in each version. Some of the improvements include fixing issues related to menu display, adding new features like edit lock and visibility rules, enhancing the user interface, and improving performance.

Overall, the mega menu add-on in Jive provides a comprehensive and customizable solution for creating and managing advanced navigation menus.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 2 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 04 January, 2023, here is the answer:
A mega menu is a type of menu that displays a large number of options in a hierarchical structure, typically in a dropdown format. It is commonly used in websites and applications to provide users with easy access to a wide range of content or features. Mega menus are often used in navigation bars or sidebars to organize and categorize complex information.

To access the Mega Menu in the given document, you need to follow these steps:
1. From the "Create" menu, select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option.
2. Next, select the "Edit" option on the top left.
3. After 30 minutes of inactivity in Edit mode, the edit lock is released.
4. Click on "Continue" in the next popup to proceed with the configuration.
5. The Mega Menu settings will now render in an editable mode.
6. To exit the Edit mode, click on "Cancel" on the top right.

The Mega Menu settings can be customized in various ways. Here are some of the key settings and features:
- General Settings: This includes options such as defining the desired menu behavior (hover or click), selecting an effect for the panel/dropdown (none, fade, slide, push), setting the speed of panel rendering, defining the line height, adding a shadow, specifying a logo image file and target link, setting the cache time for updating the Mega Menu structure, and choosing the Mega Menu position (above, below, or merged with the standard Jive header bar).
- Logo: This allows you to configure the logo for the Mega Menu and specify the URL to be accessed when the user selects the logo. You can also use the "Add Logo for Visibility Rule" feature to configure logos for each visibility rule.
- Main Navigation: This section includes options for configuring the top-level menu items, such as selecting the font family, size, color, text transform, weight, decoration, and alignment, setting the background color, spacing, padding, and divider for the items.
- Exporting/Importing Configuration: This feature allows you to export and import the current configured settings of the Mega Menu to use in another environment or instance.
- Sample Configuration: This section provides examples of different Mega Menu configurations, including sample main menus, grid menus, and tab menus.

It is important to note that the given document does not provide specific examples or detailed information about the content and structure of the Mega Menu. Therefore, for a more comprehensive understanding and implementation of the Mega Menu in Jive, it is recommended to refer to the official documentation or consult with a Jive expert.

question: Jive Add-ons
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 16 June, 2023, here is the answer:
Jive Add-ons are additional features or functionalities that can be installed and managed by Jive users. These add-ons can be used to enhance the Jive community experience and provide users with more options for collaboration and integration with other tools and services. Add-ons can be installed directly from the Jive user interface through the Add-ons Registry or by uploading a zip file.

Some examples of Jive Add-ons include:

1. Jive Connector for Hangouts: This add-on allows Jive community users to create Hangouts meetings anywhere on the site.
2. Jive Connector for Jabber: This add-on enables Jive community users to create Jabber meetings anywhere on the site.
3. Jive Connector for Skype for Business: This add-on allows Jive community users to create Skype for Business meetings anywhere on the site.
4. Jive Connector for WebEx: This add-on enables Jive community users to create WebEx meetings anywhere on the site.
5. Jive For Office: This add-on allows users to use Microsoft Office applications to create documents and save them to Jive for sharing and collaboration.
6. Jive For Outlook: This add-on allows users to utilize Jive functionality directly from Microsoft Outlook.
7. Jive for SharePoint Online & Office 365: This add-on brings the social and collaborative aspects of Jive to the SharePoint Online environment while leveraging SharePoint's document management and workflow capabilities.
8. Jive for SharePoint On-Prem: This add-on brings the social and collaborative aspects of Jive to the SharePoint on-premise environment while leveraging SharePoint's document management and workflow capabilities.
9. Lucidchart: This add-on provides collaborative diagramming capabilities for creating flowcharts, org charts, wireframes, UML diagrams, mind maps, and more.
10. Rewards and Recognition: This add-on brings gamification elements into Jive communities.
11. RSS: This add-on allows users to enrich their stream with content from RSS feeds.
12. Salesforce/Chatter: This add-on allows users to enrich their stream with content from Salesforce.
13. StreamOnce: This add-on integrates several enterprise applications with Jive to enable content streaming between the applications and Jive.
14. Twitter: This add-on brings in tweets that mention a specific handle or tweets written by members of a list and allows discussing them in Jive groups.
15. Yammer: This add-on brings in activities from a Yammer group and allows commenting on them and syncing back to Yammer.
16. Urgent Notifications: This add-on allows sending urgent notifications and collaborating on them.

It is important to note that some add-ons may require access to external services, and the availability of certain add-ons may vary depending on the Jive deployment (cloud or on-premise). Additionally, the installation and management of add-ons can be done by community managers or users with appropriate permissions.

Overall, Jive Add-ons provide users with a wide range of options to enhance their collaboration and integration experience within the Jive community.

Jive Add-ons are additional features or functionalities that can be installed and managed by Jive users. These add-ons can be used to enhance the Jive community experience and provide users with additional capabilities. Add-ons can be installed directly from the Jive user interface through the Add-ons Registry or by uploading a zip file.

Some examples of Jive Add-ons include:

1. Jive Connector for Hangouts: This add-on allows Jive community users to create Hangouts meetings anywhere on the site.
2. Jive Connector for Jabber: This add-on enables Jive community users to create Jabber meetings anywhere on the site.
3. Jive Connector for Skype for Business: This add-on allows Jive community users to create Skype for Business meetings anywhere on the site.
4. Jive Connector for WebEx: This add-on enables Jive community users to create WebEx meetings anywhere on the site.
5. Jive For Office: This add-on allows users to use Microsoft Office applications to create documents and save them to Jive for sharing and collaboration.
6. Jive For Outlook: This add-on allows users to utilize Jive functionality directly from Microsoft Outlook.
7. Jive for SharePoint Online & Office 365: This add-on brings the social and collaborative aspects of Jive to the SharePoint Online environment while leveraging SharePoint's document management and workflow capabilities.
8. Jive for SharePoint On-Prem: This add-on brings the social and collaborative aspects of Jive to the SharePoint on-premise environment while leveraging SharePoint's document management and workflow capabilities.
9. Jive Identity Connector: This add-on enables synchronizing user profiles from a Jive instance to the Jive Identity Service.
10. Lucidchart: This add-on provides collaborative diagramming capabilities for drawing flowcharts, org charts, wireframes, UML, mind maps, and more.

These add-ons can be installed and managed by community managers or users with the necessary permissions. The installation process typically involves uploading a zip file containing the add-on configuration and assets. Once installed, the add-ons can be used to enhance the functionality and collaboration within the Jive community.

It's important to note that some add-ons may require access to external services or may have specific requirements for installation and usage. It's recommended to review the documentation and requirements for each add-on before installation.

If you have specific questions about Jive Add-ons or need assistance with installation or usage, you can refer to the Jive Developers community or reach out to other developers for support. The Jive Developers community provides a platform for developers to connect, ask questions, and learn more about developing with Jive.

question: Mega Menu
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 4 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
Yes, it is possible to use a mega menu in Jive. The mega menu feature allows for advanced navigation configuration and customization. To access the mega menu, you can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, you can edit the mega menu by selecting the "Edit" option on the top left. The mega menu settings can be configured in an editable mode, and you can exit the edit mode by clicking on "Cancel" on the top right.

The mega menu settings include various options such as defining the desired menu behavior (hover or click), selecting an effect for the panel/dropdown (none, fade, slide, push), setting the speed of panel rendering, defining the line height, adding a shadow, linking a logo image file, setting a target link for the logo, specifying the cache time for the mega menu structure, choosing the position of the mega menu (above, below, or merged with the standard Jive header bar), and making the mega menu sticky to fix or scroll it.

In addition to the general settings, you can also configure specific elements of the mega menu, such as the logo, main navigation (top level menu items), dropdown panel, grid (column), sub-menu items (level 2), and third level menu items. Each element has its own set of options for customization, including font settings, background colors, padding, borders, and more.

To manage the mega menu, you can create new menu items, edit existing items, add sub-menu items, delete items, and rearrange the menu items using the provided icons. You can also create translations for different languages, create dropdown menus in both vertical tab and grid styles, and configure visibility rules for specific menu items based on user profiles.

It is important to note that there may be some limitations and issues with the mega menu feature, such as the logo not appearing for external users if it uses a URL that they don't have access to. In such cases, it is recommended to upload the logo as a static resource to ensure visibility for all users.

Overall, the mega menu feature in Jive provides a comprehensive and customizable navigation solution for intranets and communities.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 4 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
Yes, it is possible to use a mega menu in Jive. The mega menu feature allows for advanced navigation configuration and customization. To access the mega menu, you can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, you can edit the mega menu by selecting the "Edit" option on the top left. The mega menu settings can be configured in an editable mode, and you can exit the edit mode by clicking on "Cancel" on the top right.

The mega menu settings include various options such as defining the desired menu behavior (hover or click), selecting an effect for the panel/dropdown (none, fade, slide, push), setting the speed of panel rendering, defining the line height, adding a shadow, specifying a logo image file and target link, setting the cache time for the mega menu structure, and choosing the position of the mega menu (above, below, or merged with the standard Jive header bar). Additionally, there is an option to make the mega menu sticky, which allows it to be fixed or scrollable.

The mega menu can be further customized by configuring settings for the general settings, logo, main navigation, top-level menu items, dropdown panel, grid (column), sub-menu items (level 2), and third-level menu items. Each of these settings has its own set of options and configurations, such as defining font styles, colors, backgrounds, padding, borders, and visibility rules.

To export or import the configuration of the mega menu, you can use the Export/Import feature. This feature allows you to save and transfer the configured settings to another environment or instance. You can also save previous configurations as backups using this feature.

The mega menu add-on has undergone several updates and improvements over time. The release notes provide detailed information about the changes and fixes made in each version. Some of the improvements include fixing issues related to menu display, translation rules, visibility rules, and UI compatibility. The add-on also supports features like edit lock, permission-based menu editing, and visibility rules based on user profiles.

In conclusion, the mega menu feature in Jive allows for advanced navigation configuration and customization. It provides various options for menu settings, layout, styling, and visibility rules. The add-on has undergone continuous updates and improvements to enhance its functionality and address any issues or bugs.

question: Mega Menu Add-on
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 2 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 25 April, 2023, here is the answer:
The Mega Menu Add-On allows users to create and configure a mega menu for their Jive instance. The menu can be customized with various settings and elements to create a visually appealing and user-friendly navigation experience.

To access the Mega Menu, users can go to the "Create" menu and select the "Advanced Navigation Configuration" option. From there, they can select the "Edit" option to make changes to the menu.

The menu settings can be customized in the Theme page by adding custom CSS. Users can add custom CSS to hide certain elements or modify the position of the menu. After making changes, users can save the theme.

To configure the Mega Menu Add-On, users can go to the configuration page via the URL: \`/apps/mega-menu-add-on\`. From there, they can configure various settings such as the menu behavior, effects, speed, line height, logo, cache time, position, and sticky behavior.

The Mega Menu Add-On also supports visibility rules, which allow users to control the visibility of menu items based on user profiles. Users can create visibility rules and specify conditions for when the menu items should be displayed. The visibility rules can be managed and edited in the configuration panel.

Users can also create dropdown menus within the mega menu. They can add sub-menu items, edit their details, and manage the menu items. Dropdown menus can be created in both grid and vertical tab styles.

The Mega Menu Add-On also provides options for exporting and importing the configuration, as well as sample configurations for reference.

In terms of installation, the Mega Menu Add-On can be installed on both cloud and hosted/on-prem Jive instances. The installation process involves creating user groups, setting system properties, uploading the add-on package, and configuring the add-on settings.

Overall, the Mega Menu Add-On provides users with a powerful tool to create and customize a mega menu for their Jive instance, enhancing the navigation experience for users.

question: How to set kubectl to access MAKO?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set kubectl to access MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. Download the Maven binary from the Maven website. You can find the download link [here](http://maven.apache.org/download.html).
2. Unpack the binary on your system. If you are using a Mac, explode the zip file to /usr/local. If you are using Windows, extract the downloaded Maven zip file to the root of the C: drive, which will create a maven-2.2.1 folder.
3. Set your environment path. If you are using a Mac, add a M2_HOME environment variable to your ~/.bash_profile and point it to your download. For example:
\`\`\`
export M2_HOME=/usr/local/apache-maven-2.2.1
\`\`\`
Also, add the $M2_HOME/bin directory to your path, before /usr/bin.
If you are using Windows, adjust the System Path Variable by appending a semi-colon and the location of the maven\bin directory. For example:
\`\`\`
C:\maven-2.2.1\bin
\`\`\`
4. Test your installation by running the command \`mvn --version\`. You should see the Apache Maven version and Java version information.

Please note that the provided information is based on the extracted parts of a long document and may not cover all possible scenarios. It is always recommended to refer to the official documentation or seek assistance from the relevant support channels for specific instructions related to your environment.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To set up kubectl to access MAKO, you need to follow these steps:

1. First, make sure you have the Jive Apps Command Line Tools installed on your system. If not, you can install it by running the following command in the terminal:
\`\`\`
sudo gem install jiveapps
\`\`\`

2. Once the Jive Apps Command Line Tools are installed, you need to configure Git. Run the following commands in the terminal to set your Git username and email:
\`\`\`
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your_email@example.com"
\`\`\`

3. Next, generate an SSH key pair if you don't already have one. Run the following command in the terminal and press Enter at all prompts:
\`\`\`
ssh-keygen -t rsa -C "your_email@example.com"
\`\`\`

4. Install Git if you don't have it already. You can download the Git installer for your operating system from the official Git website and follow the installation instructions.

5. Once Git is installed, you can set up your SSH keys. Copy the public key generated in step 3 (usually located in the \`~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub\` file) and add it to your MAKO account settings. This will allow you to authenticate with MAKO using your SSH key.

6. Finally, you can configure kubectl to access MAKO. Run the following command in the terminal:
\`\`\`
kubectl config set-cluster mako --server=https://mako.example.com --certificate-authority=path/to/ca.crt
kubectl config set-credentials mako --client-certificate=path/to/client.crt --client-key=path/to/client.key
kubectl config set-context mako --cluster=mako --user=mako
kubectl config use-context mako
\`\`\`
Replace \`https://mako.example.com\` with the URL of your MAKO server, and replace \`path/to/ca.crt\`, \`path/to/client.crt\`, and \`path/to/client.key\` with the paths to your CA certificate, client certificate, and client key files respectively.

After completing these steps, you should be able to use kubectl to access MAKO.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers are somewhat similar, as they both provide instructions on how to set up kubectl to access MAKO. However, the search_phrase_answer provides additional instructions for installing the Jive Apps Command Line Tools, configuring Git, generating an SSH key pair, and installing Git, which the original answer does not include.

question: what is jive rewards?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 8 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 November, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive Rewards is a set of features built into Jive's cloud platform that enables the use of gamification to motivate people to participate in the community. It includes elements such as events, points, levels, leaderboards, missions, strategies, quests, and badges. However, it is recommended to review the configuration settings before launching to ensure that rewards are given for activities that align with the community's specific goals.

To set up Jive Rewards, simple setup activities can be carried out to personalize it and align it with the community's goals and culture. These activities include reviewing the configuration settings, adjusting rewards for specific activities, and personalizing the rewards system.

For more information and guidance on implementing a gamification program for a community, users can contact their Account Manager or Customer Success Manager to discuss engagement with the Professional Services team.

Jive Rewards is a set of features built into Jive's cloud platform that enables the use of gamification to motivate people to participate in the community. It includes elements such as events, points, levels, leaderboards, missions, strategies, quests, and badges. Using gamification in a community can help promote and accelerate onboarding for new members, drive desirable behaviors, indicate reputation and achievements, and increase overall usage and engagement. Jive Rewards has default configurations that can be adjusted to align with the community's specific goals. It is recommended to review the configuration settings before launching the rewards program.

The elements of Jive Rewards include events, points, levels, leaderboards, missions, strategies, quests, and badges. Events are actions that people perform in the community, such as liking a post or commenting on content. Points are awarded for completing events, missions, strategies, and quests, and they contribute to a person's level in the community. Leaderboards show the ranking of individuals based on their points totals. Missions track specific events and level up as users repeat those activities, while strategies roll up missions and also level up. Badges are given to individuals when they complete missions, strategies, or quests, and they appear on their profile as a notation of their accomplishments.

To set up Jive Rewards, it is recommended to carry out some simple setup activities to personalize it and ensure it aligns with the community's goals and culture. Jive Rewards can work straight out of the box, but customization can enhance its effectiveness. There are resources available, such as a Rewards strategy worksheet and documentation, to help with the setup process.

For more information and guidance on implementing a gamification program for a community, it is advised to contact the Account Manager or Customer Success Manager to discuss the possibility of engaging with the Professional Services team.

question: What was in the Jive 9.07 release?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 11 March, 2022, here is the answer:
The Jive 9.07 release introduced several new features and improvements. Some of the key highlights of this release include:

1. Engagement Analytics: Jive 9.07 introduced Engagement Analytics, which provides detailed insights into user interactions and community participation. Community managers can analyze user interactions by job type, title, location, department, and other values to gauge the health and vibrancy of the community. The Engagement Index chart allows organizations to track community engagement and user activity over time.

2. Jive Daily: Jive Daily is now a mobile app for Jive-n users. It allows employees to stay connected to their Jive-n company intranet or employee community from anywhere. With Jive Daily, users can read company news, follow personalized activity streams, get notifications, create and edit content, search people and places, vote on polls and ideas, RSVP to events, and more.

3. Content Management: Jive 9.07 introduced bulk content management, which allows users to quickly and easily modify multiple pieces of content within a place. Users can add categories and tags, move or delete content, and set outcomes in bulk. They can also bulk upload multiple files, associate tags with batch uploads, and manage image galleries more efficiently. Additionally, Jive 9.07 introduced the "Copy Document" action, which allows users to clone the title, body, and publishing information of a document into a new piece of content.

4. New Tiles: Jive 9.07 made several improvements to tiles and introduced new tiles. These improvements were based on user feedback and aimed to enhance the overall user experience.

It is important to note that the information provided is based on the extracted parts of the document, and there may be additional features and improvements in the Jive 9.07 release that are not mentioned. For more detailed information, it is recommended to refer to the official release notes and documentation provided by Jive.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 11 March, 2022, here is the answer:
Jive 9.0.7 is a release for Jive Hosted and On-Premise communities. It was announced on April 5, 2019, and is now available. The release includes several new features and improvements. To get more details about the release, you can refer to the following resources:

- [Jive 9.0.7 Release for Jive Hosted and On-Premise communities is Now Available!](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/community/customers/blog/2019/04/05/jive-907-release-for-jive-hosted-and-on-premise-communities-is-now-available)
- [Release Notes – Jive Hosted on Premise (9.0.0–9.1.0)](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/docs/DOC-213943)

The release introduces several key features, including Engagement Analytics, Jive Daily, and Content Management enhancements. Here are some highlights of what's new in Jive 9.0.7:

- **Engagement Analytics**: This feature provides detailed insights into user interactions that drive community participation and performance. Community managers can analyze user interactions by job type, title, location, department, and other values to gauge the health and vibrancy of the community.
- **Jive Daily**: Jive Daily is now a mobile app for Jive-n users, allowing employees to stay connected to the company intranet or employee community. It offers features such as inbox notifications, news feed and activity streams, search functionality, content viewing and creation, and more.
- **Content Management**: The release includes bulk content management capabilities, allowing users to quickly modify multiple pieces of content within a place. Users can also copy documents to create templates or publish them under different contexts.

Please note that the information provided is based on the extracted parts of the document, and for more detailed information, it is recommended to refer to the provided links and resources.

question: For what purpose Jive uses kubernetes ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 November, 2021, here is the answer:
Jive uses Kubernetes for the purpose of creating a centralized knowledge hub where information can flow between Aurea internal employees, the partner network, and customers. Kubernetes allows Jive to access and manage the centralized knowledge, facilitating better support, faster turnaround times, and leveraging knowledge provided by the community and teams. Jive serves as the hub to access the centralized knowledge, enabling collaboration and information sharing among different stakeholders. The use of Kubernetes in this context helps Jive in achieving its goal of providing a platform for collaboration and knowledge management.



Jive is used for various purposes within organizations. It serves as a social collaboration tool that breaks down walls between functional areas, allowing people to connect, share ideas, and collaborate. Jive facilitates innovation, helps people get valuable information, and solves problems faster. It enables global businesses to share good ideas quickly and efficiently. Jive also acts as a comprehensive platform that replaces multiple tools such as pages, blogging tools, search and indexing tools, file sharing tools, and project management tools. It provides seamless functionality, increased effectiveness, and efficiency in communication and collaboration.



Regarding the specific question about federating to Jive and using single sign-on (SSO) with other SaaS propositions, there is no explicit information provided in the given extracted parts of the document. Therefore, it is not possible to provide a definitive answer to this question based on the available information.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 19 October, 2019, here is the answer:
Jive is a social collaboration tool for business that breaks down walls between functional areas, allowing people who might never meet to connect, share ideas, and collaborate. This collaboration can facilitate and speed innovation as well as help people get more valuable information and solve problems faster in the time-crunch of everyday work. Jive is an enterprise collaboration platform that bridges the way people use collaborative tools outside of work into the work environment by socializing project and document management, and knowledge sharing. It has strong internal and external use cases designed to provide documented ROI in many different ways, while at the same time leveraging the efficiencies and differentiation that comes along with socialized mediums.

One use case for Jive is creating Jive groups for each class that is taught, whether in-person or virtual. These groups are used for posting links to resources and course materials, video demonstrations, Q&A during the class, and uploading of assignments. When the class ends, participants are off-boarded into groups relevant to their jobs where the conversations continue with all their peers. These groups become knowledge repositories on specific topics and help participants gain the knowledge they need for their job roles. Jive also makes it easier for people to find mentors and ask questions.

Another use case for Jive is as a comprehensive platform that replaces multiple tools such as pages, blogging tools, search and indexing tools, file sharing tools, collaboration tools, and project management tools. Jive provides seamless functionality and increased effectiveness and efficiency. It allows for easy access to information and collaboration, eliminating the need for multiple tools and improving productivity.

Jive can also be used to gamify social collaboration in the workplace. It offers built-in or third-party opportunities to make knowledge sharing and collaboration fun and engaging. This can motivate employees to participate and contribute more actively, leading to increased engagement and productivity.

Jive can be integrated with other systems such as SharePoint to streamline processes, integrate systems, and promote external system activity throughout the enterprise. The rich APIs of Jive and SharePoint allow for creative solution architects and developers to solve challenges and create real-world solutions.

In summary, Jive has various use cases in R&D, including creating groups for classes, knowledge repositories, replacing multiple tools, gamifying social collaboration, and integrating with other systems. These use cases can help convince management to adopt Jive for improved collaboration and productivity.

question: what all do you know about?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 June, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive is a social software platform that offers a better way to work and helps users feel more connected. It combines the features of popular social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter with additional functionalities. Jive allows users to collaborate, communicate, and share information within their organization. It provides tools for creating discussions, asking questions, and sharing knowledge. Jive also offers training resources, such as videos and articles, to help users learn and utilize the platform effectively. Overall, Jive is a comprehensive social collaboration tool that enhances productivity and connectivity in the workplace.

Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 June, 2020, here is the answer:
Jive is a social collaboration platform that allows users to connect, share, and collaborate with others in a work environment. It combines elements of social networking sites like Facebook and LinkedIn with additional features and capabilities. Jive provides a better way to work by improving communication, fostering collaboration, and increasing connectivity among employees.

In layman's terms, Jive can be described as a platform that helps people work together more effectively. It allows users to ask questions, share information, and feel more connected to their colleagues. Jive offers various tools and features that enable users to collaborate on projects, share knowledge, and stay updated on important information.

Jive is not limited to just social networking; it goes beyond that by providing a comprehensive set of features and functionalities that enhance productivity and facilitate teamwork. It is like Facebook and LinkedIn, but on steroids, as it offers more advanced capabilities tailored for the workplace.

To explain Jive to a random employee, you can use the following pitch:
"Do you want a better way to work? Do you want to feel more connected? Jive is a platform that allows you to collaborate with your colleagues, share information, and stay updated on important matters. It's like Facebook and LinkedIn, but specifically designed for the workplace. With Jive, you can ask questions, share knowledge, and work together more effectively."

Please note that the information provided is based on the extracted parts of the document, and there may be additional details about Jive that are not included.

question: AWS Instance (Minimal Usage) Management
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 June, 2020, here is the answer:
**AWS Instance (Minimal Usage) Management**

To manage an AWS instance with minimal usage, follow these steps:

1. Determine the type of information needed for your instance. This includes the Jive Software version, Tenant ID, Instance IP Address, and the Shared Services your community leverages. The Jive version can be found in the top right corner of your Jive admin console, the Tenant ID is located on the System Information screen, and the Instance IP Address can be obtained from your IT department.

2. Provide your system properties if you are using any of the shared services. This information will help ensure the smooth operation of your instance.

3. Contact your Account Manager for assistance with renewing your Jive contract. They will be able to guide you through the process and address any concerns you may have.

4. Stay informed about the upgrade process and schedule. Check the provided resources and FAQs to learn about the benefits of Jive's infrastructure and architecture transition, enhanced disaster recovery, Jive Cloud versions, and new features and enhancements included in the upgrade.

5. Prepare your community for the Cloud upgrade and migration to AWS. Follow the guidelines and recommendations provided to ensure a seamless transition.

6. Monitor the performance and availability of your community in AWS. Jive communities are scaled to have at least two instances in different data centers, with larger communities having more instances. Instances are continuously monitored, and adjustments are made as required to ensure optimal performance and availability.

7. Familiarize yourself with the security-oriented information provided. As a customer using Jive Cloud on AWS, you benefit from a data center and infrastructure built to meet the requirements of security-sensitive organizations.

8. Take advantage of the additional resources and assets provided to learn more about the upgrade process, disaster recovery, AWS infrastructure and security, and Jive Cloud features and enhancements.

9. If you have any additional questions or need further assistance, contact your Account Manager. They are there to help and address any concerns you may have.

Please note that the provided information is based on the extracted parts of the document, and it is recommended to refer to the complete document for a comprehensive understanding of AWS instance management with minimal usage.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 07 June, 2020, here is the answer:
**AWS Instance management best practices**

When managing AWS instances, there are several best practices that can help ensure optimal performance, security, and availability. Here are some key recommendations:

1. **Regularly update and patch your instances**: Keeping your instances up to date with the latest security patches and updates is crucial for maintaining a secure environment. AWS provides tools like AWS Systems Manager and AWS Patch Manager to help automate this process.

2. **Implement proper security measures**: AWS offers a wide range of security features that should be utilized to protect your instances. This includes using strong passwords, enabling multi-factor authentication (MFA), and configuring security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to control inbound and outbound traffic.

3. **Monitor and optimize performance**: Monitoring the performance of your instances is essential for identifying any bottlenecks or issues. AWS CloudWatch provides monitoring and alerting capabilities, allowing you to track metrics such as CPU utilization, network traffic, and disk I/O. Additionally, you can use AWS Auto Scaling to automatically adjust the capacity of your instances based on demand.

4. **Implement backup and disaster recovery strategies**: It is important to have a backup and disaster recovery plan in place to protect your data in case of any unforeseen events. AWS offers services like Amazon S3 for storing backups and Amazon Glacier for long-term archival storage. You can also use AWS Backup to automate the backup process.

5. **Implement proper access controls**: Controlling access to your instances is crucial for maintaining security. Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to manage user access and permissions. Additionally, consider implementing least privilege principles, where users are only given the minimum level of access required to perform their tasks.

6. **Implement logging and auditing**: Enabling logging and auditing is important for monitoring and troubleshooting your instances. AWS CloudTrail can be used to track API calls and AWS Config can be used to monitor and manage the configuration of your instances.

7. **Regularly review and optimize costs**: AWS offers various pricing models and cost optimization tools that can help you optimize your costs. Regularly review your usage and consider using services like AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Budgets to monitor and control your costs.

It is important to note that these best practices are general recommendations and may vary depending on your specific requirements and use cases. It is always recommended to consult AWS documentation and seek expert advice when implementing instance management best practices.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided for this question are somewhat similar as they both discuss AWS instance management. However, the search_phrase_answer provides more detailed information about best practices and recommendations, while the original answer focuses on steps to manage an AWS instance with minimal usage.

question: where I can find sensitive information?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 05 June, 2020, here is the answer:
To find sensitive information, it is important to have a standardized process for gathering employee information. Currently, the organization is facing challenges with lack of standardization and poor user experience. They are looking for a digital solution where employees can fill out an online form and submit it securely to the right person. One suggestion is to use SurveyMonkey, which offers HIPAA compliance and separate accounts for each team under one enterprise license. This solution provides a specific URL for each form and can accommodate multiple dozens of forms.

In another thread, a user is looking for a way to filter out sensitive content in their open Jive intranet. They want to create a customized experience for users who do not want to see sensitive content. One suggestion is to flag or tag the content as "sensitive" and hide it from users who fall into a certain security group. Another suggestion is to create a secret or private group specifically for sensitive topics and allow users to join the group if they want to see the content. It is important to educate users about what is considered sensitive and provide mechanisms for reporting and removing inappropriate content.

In terms of collecting information, one user is looking for strategies to research prospects for their SDRs. They are specifically interested in advanced tools and techniques. Unfortunately, there is no specific information provided in the extracted parts of the document to answer this question.

Another user is interested in getting an analytic report regarding the storage of contents such as blogs and documents. They want to know how to find the size of blogs or documents on a monthly or yearly basis. However, there is no information provided in the extracted parts of the document to answer this question.

In terms of managing asset classification and blocking the creation and uploading of secret information, one user suggests turning off personal containers and using a Silencer Plug-in to block public posting of content. They also mention the importance of data handling policies and permissions to control access to sensitive information.

Regarding the risk assessment of third-party vendors related to information security, one user suggests reaching out to Jive's account representative for a detailed white paper on their security policies and procedures. They also mention the Trust & Security page on jivesoftware.com as a helpful resource.

In terms of preventing accidental public posting of confidential information, one user suggests using the email analogy and educating employees about what and what not to post. They emphasize the importance of holding employees accountable, educating them, and trusting them to follow the rules. They also mention the availability of mechanisms such as the Report Abuse button to notify administrators of inappropriate content.

In terms of confidentiality and access to highly sensitive information, there is no specific information provided in the extracted parts of the document to answer this question.

Regarding the availability of the Jive SharePoint Connector, one user suggests reaching out to the support group or contacting the sales team at Jive Software for assistance.

Overall, the extracted parts of the document provide some insights into managing sensitive information and gathering employee information, but there is limited information to answer the question of where to find sensitive information.

question: tell me about the Jive customer Ministry of Defence
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 October, 2017, here is the answer:
**Jive** is a software platform that enables collaboration and communication within organizations. It allows employees to connect, share information, and work together more effectively. Jive offers various features such as document sharing, discussion forums, and social networking capabilities.

Unfortunately, there is not enough information provided to specifically address the question about the Jive customer Ministry of Defence.

Jive chubb customer refers to the use of the Jive platform by Chubb Insurance, a global property and casualty insurance firm. Chubb used Jive for corporate social engagement, while ACE used Jive for their intranet. After the merger of the two companies, they merged both platforms into one instance called Village. The purpose of using Jive in this context was to bring together the systems and capabilities of both companies and create a unified platform for communication and collaboration.

During a presentation by Howard Cohen, he outlined several key points related to the use of Jive at Chubb Insurance. He discussed the historical use of Jive at both ACE and Chubb, highlighting the differences between the two systems and how they were brought together. He also mentioned a specific use case around Working Out Loud and shared some ROI stats to demonstrate the value of the platform. Additionally, he talked about future plans to extend the capabilities of the platform and gave a live demo.

question: tell me about the Jive customer morgan stanley
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 10 October, 2017, here is the answer:
Jive is a platform that allows companies to connect with their customers and partners, providing a better customer and partner experience. It consolidates multiple systems onto one platform, allowing front-line employees to resolve customer queries on the first contact, regardless of the channel. Jive also facilitates collaboration and communication around customers, making it easier for different departments to engage in discussions about specific customer accounts. The platform is designed to enhance information design and content management.

Jive has been used by various companies, including T-Mobile, Marketstar, Steelcase, and Johnson Controls, to better connect with their customers and partners. These companies have shared real-world examples of how they have leveraged Jive to improve customer and partner engagement. They have also used advanced gamification techniques to drive engagement and have seen positive results.

Unfortunately, there is no specific information available about Jive's use by Morgan Stanley.

question: What is the latest version of Jive Cloud?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 December, 2021, here is the answer:
The latest version of Jive Cloud is **3006.10.0.3**. This release was deployed to production on **December 4, 2021**. It eliminates a security issue found since the last release. For more information about this release and its scope, you can refer to the **Jive Cloud Release Schedule** document available at [https://thrive.ignitetech.com/docs/DOC-259980](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/docs/DOC-259980).
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 10 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 11 January, 2022, here is the answer:
The latest version of Jive Cloud is the 2016.2 Release. This release was rolled out to all Wave 3, Jive-n, and Jive-x Cloud instances on Saturday, August 13th, 2016. If you have any support-related questions, you can contact the support team at [Support](https://thrive.ignitetech.com/community/support). Thank you for your patience during the upgrade.
answer_similarity_reason: The two answers provided are not very similar. The first answer provides information about the latest version of Jive Cloud and its release date, while the second answer provides information about the 2016.2 Release and its deployment date.

question: What is bunchball ?
original_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 October, 2021, here is the answer:
Bunchball is a gamification module that can be integrated with Jive, a community and collaboration platform. It allows organizations to create incentive systems, missions, badges, and events to encourage positive and productive behavior within their community. Bunchball provides a platform for tracking actions and activity, displaying results, and rewarding users with points and recognition.

According to the extracted parts of the document, Bunchball has been used by some hosted or on-prem customers of Jive. However, there are also mentions of Bunchball no longer being supported and not being connected to Jive anymore. It is unclear from the given information whether Bunchball is still actively maintained and updated for use with Jive.

The success of Bunchball implementation depends on various factors. Some users have reported notable success and valuable outcomes, such as increased engagement, high-value activities, and business results. However, it is important to note that the success of gamification initiatives relies on careful planning, customization, and alignment with the organization's culture and community objectives. Creating a game that works for the organization's specific context and setting the tone from the start are crucial. Emphasizing quality by rewarding recognition from others and launching with a big splash can also contribute to the success of the gamification program. It is recommended to plan for the long haul, have a sufficient number of missions planned, and watch out for cheaters to maintain the integrity of the game.

Regarding updates and support for Bunchball, the information is limited. There are mentions of Bunchball being updated for minor releases and having constant minor updates. However, it is unclear how frequently Bunchball is updated specifically for use with Jive. There is also a mention of a new Nitro Studio console that could potentially enhance the Bunchball experience, but it is not clear if and when this update will be incorporated into the Jive Gamification Module.

In summary, Bunchball is a gamification module that can be integrated with Jive to create incentive systems, missions, badges, and events to encourage positive behavior and engagement within a community. The success of Bunchball implementation depends on careful planning, customization, and alignment with the organization's objectives. The availability of updates and support for Bunchball specifically for use with Jive is unclear from the given information.
search_phrase_answer:
Based on the information I have, which includes 9 potentially relevant documents, the latest of which is dated 06 October, 2021, here is the answer:
**Bunchball** refers to a gamification module that was integrated with the Jive platform. It allowed organizations to implement game-like elements, such as missions, badges, and leaderboards, to engage and motivate users within their Jive community. The Bunchball integration enabled users to earn points and rewards for participating in desired behaviors and activities, ultimately driving engagement and fostering a sense of competition and achievement.

However, based on the extracted parts of the document, it appears that the Bunchball integration is no longer supported or connected to Jive. The content related to Bunchball is being considered for removal, as it is no longer relevant. Some customers may still be using Bunchball, but it is not clear if they are using it with the Jive platform or on its own.

It is worth noting that the Bunchball Wiki mentioned in the document is reserved for customers using the Nitro Platform, which can be licensed by Jive customers to expand the systems they are gamifying outside of only Jive. If organizations are interested in exploring the capabilities of the Nitro platform, they are advised to contact their Jive account manager, who can initiate conversations with the Bunchball team.

In summary, Bunchball was a gamification module integrated with the Jive platform, but it appears that the integration is no longer supported or connected to Jive. The content related to Bunchball is being considered for removal, and it is unclear if any customers are currently using Bunchball with Jive. The Bunchball Wiki mentioned in the document is reserved for customers using the Nitro Platform, which can be licensed separately from Jive.

The main difference between the two answers is that the search_phrase_answer provides more detailed information about the Nitro Platform and its potential use with Bunchball.
